text:
This wasn't bad but I did not think it tasted much like true rotisserie chicken bought at a market, etc. True rotisserie chicken has that great, mellow roasted taste - not a spicy taste. This wasn't spicy "hot" just overpowering -- it buried that great roast chicken flavor under all the spices. I hoped to use the leftovers for a curry chicken salad the next day but the spices permeated the meat so much I actually went out and bought a rotisserie chicken to use instead. I worried the spices would change the taste of the chicken salad. I don't know that I'll make this again. I'm more a fan of the Barefoot Contessa roast chicken recipe. As for rotisserie chickens, I'll stick to the ones at the market done in a true rotisserie until I find a recipe I like better.

When I see a recipe on this website with so many wonderful reviews, I MUST try it!  Well, this certainly lived up to the reviews. I had one 7.5 lb roaster. I made the spice mixture as listed (cut down on the salt). I rubbed the spices on and under the skin.  I let it sit in the refrigerator for about 6 hours. I put it in a 250 degree oven. Everyone that said their house smelled great wasnt kidding!  It was ready after 3.5 hours. I let it sit (cause rest of dinner wasnt finished). I really had my doubts until I started to carve it. It was SO juicy and incredibly delicious! My (17 yo) daughter felt it was too spicy, but I loved it!  I made a chicken salad sandwich from the scraps of leftovers for my lunch today. WOW!

text:
FABULOUS chicken!  I made it for the second time last night.  The first time I followed the recipe exactly and thought it was great.  This time I reduced the salt by half.  Also, I was running short on time yesterday so I put half of the spice rub UNDER the skin, marinated only 2 hours, bumped the oven up to 300, and cooked for 2.5 - 3 hours.  It's good enough to stand alone, but if you're a "saucey" person like me use some of the drippings to make a great cream gravy.  Generally, I use about 1/2 cup drippings, just enough flour to absorb drippings, and then add milk a little at a time over med-lo heat until desired consistency and flavor.  And like another reviewer said, pour some of the drippings over the top just before serving for a nice glistening presentation.  The family loved it before, but they thought it was even better this time.

OMG! I made this last night for my father in law's birthday dinner, it was the best chicken that any of us ever had! My 4 yr old son & 6 yr old daughter could'nt get enough!! Wow, this is the oly way I will make roasted chicken again. I had an 8 lb chicken, doubled the seasonings (except the cayenne & salt), put the seasonings in a shaker and rubbed it under the skin as well as over it. I quartered an onion put it in the cavity-meant to add garlic but forgot-Then I wrapped in saran wrap, put in fridge for 4 hrs and then cooked it for 5 at 250. YUMMY!!!!!!!! Today I made soup with the dark meat and bones and the broth is a little on the spicy side.

text:
Very very good - made the whole house smell great.  I ground all the spices in a spice mill to mix them evenly together (using all black pepper and only 1/2 the cayenne).  The kids, who usually complain whenever I use even the smallest amount of cayenne, didn't notice a thing - the long roasting time must have mellowed the "heat", so next time I'll put it all in.  I hate the laborious task of basting, so I schmeared olive oil all over the chickens before sprinkling and rubbing with the seasoning mix (right in the roasting pan) - which made for a messy experience, but it resulted in nice crispy skin - hubby LOVED the flavor!  For presentation at the table, I did pour some of the pan juices over the birds to make them nice and shiny.  I also poured some of the pan juices over cooked white rice - YUM-O!  I only gave 4 stars because cooking time was a bit off in my professional range which is correctly calibrated - I used 5 lb. birds instead of 4 lb. ones, and after 5 1/2 hours their internal temp was 175.  After resting for 10-15 minutes their internal temp had risen to 188 - the white meat was a bit dry, but the pan drippings helped with that.  The dark meat on the other hand (or should I say leg) was fabulous!  I'll use an internal thermometer next time.  I'd also like to try just legs and thighs as one reviewer suggested by roasting at 250 for 3 hrs.

UPDATE to 5 stars.  I made this recipe again using all the cayenne and bone-in skinless thighs.  I added a few cut up onions t

Not one morsel of this chicken was left for me to even make soup with, which I will say is a first.  We had an unexpected guest, which made us 3 adults, two teens (yes, even my non-meat eating daughter ate some...odd) and a 5 year old.  I have a rotisserie spit for my grill and I thought of pulling it out, but then decided ah, too much trouble so I did it in the oven with awesome results..obviously if I don't have any left.  I added chicken broth (1 cup) and cut potatoes & carrots to the chickens for the last 2 hours of roasting.  Will definately make this again, but will double the spice recipe...make sure you pat the chicken dry before rubbing that on.  Thanks so much Sue!!

I didn't decide on this until it was too late to refrigerate it for long, so it only got about an hour with the rub on it.  Started baking it at 250F, then realized we'd be eating too late, so inched it up to 275F, then 300F.  It was in the oven for about 4.5 hours.  I also basted it for about the last hour.  There were lots of juices and meat fell off the bone and had nice flavor.  Would've been nice if I'd placed it in the baking pan breast side up, but didn't affect it badly. :-)

text:
I now make chicken this way regularly!  Some tips:  popping the chick under the broiler for the last 15-20 minutes will make the skin wonderfully crispy.  Also, I often make this with NO seasonings!  And it's still terrific.  Also, you can use this same technique for leg quarters or thighs.  (But not breast pieces; those turn out too dry.)  BTW, even my FIL, who isn't lavish with praise, complemented me on this chicken!

text:
I have made my version of this for years, and it's delicious.  I stuff the cavity with 1/2 lemon and 1/2 bulb of garlic.  Also, if you really want to be decadent, brush the chicken with melted butter for crispy skin!

I also chop up onion, red potatoes, and fennel and roast the whole time in the bottom of the pan--just plop the bird on top of them.  Like the juices, they also caramelize as they cook. Easy, delicious, and impressive enough for company. Not to mention it makes the house smell wonderful!

I roasted 1 whole 7lb chicken with all ingredients listed, plus 3 garlic gloves, 1 lemon and a handful of fresh parsely stuffed in the cavity. I roasted at 500 degrees for 45 min, breast side down and then turning chicken over halfway through on a roasting pan with a rack, then I lowered the temp down to 250 and continued roasting for 3 hours, basting it once with broth. It was so delicious! I look forward to making it again.

Didn't have time to marinate at all, but it still tasted great!  I used up all the seasoning mix on one chicken, and cooked for 4 hours, per others' recommendations.  Took off as much fat as I could from the drippings, added 1 cup of chicken broth, whisked, brought just to a boil over med. high heat, whisked in a TB of butter, and finally, poured through a sieve for a great gravy.  Ohhhh yummmmm!  Should have used no salt added broth, but otherwise, a perfect complement to a perfect recipe.  My husband was uncomfortable afterwards b/c he ate so much.  Thanks again for a great Sunday dinner you can make on the cheap!

I made this over the weekend and everyone really liked it.  I did play around with the spices a bit to suit my family's taste.  I also increased the oven temperature to 275 degrees. The one change I would make to this recipe is to add a small amount of brown sugar to the rub.  That would give the skin the "stickiness" that the recipe implies.

text:
This recipe was as great as everyone said it was -- and so simple!  I made a single chicken that was just a hair under 6 pounds.  I used my convection oven to roast it at 250 degrees, and it took about 2 hours and 45 minutes.  It rested for about 40 minutes or so.  It literally was falling off of the bones.  My only problem is that I'm lousy at carving so it wasn't as beautiful on the serving plate, but my husband didn't care.  He raved about the chicken and said I have to make it again.  I totally forgot to season the cavity with the spice mixture (I was tired when I remembered to rub it down and get it marinating the night before), but I did put two small quartered onions and about 4 or 5 peeled garlic cloves inside.  The flavor from the veggies and the spices really went throughout the meat.  This is the best roasted chicken I've ever made.  Next time I think I'm going to try it on my rotisserie.  It may even go onto next year's Thanksgiving turkey.  My ONLY complaint (and it's a small one) is that it seemed a tad bit salty.  I may cut back on that just a bit next time.  Otherwise it was PERFECT, and we both loved it!

Delicious! The meat, even the breast, was juicy and tender; the skin crispy, the exact results I wanted. I cooked it in a broiler pan over the rack, so I didn't bother to baste at all. I'll definitely be making this again and play around with other seasonings. Thanks Sue.

text:
My husband and two small children loved this recipe. 

I enclosed my birds in foil instead of cooking them open - to ensure that they stayed tender as I saw most of the complaints said it was too dry. My birds were not at all dry. 

 I also let my chickens marinade for 36 hours instead of the directed 6.

After marinading them I added a whole garlic bulb between the two birds and stuffed inside with the onion before cooking.

I cooked at 250 for 2 1/2 hours and raised it to 300 for a hour and a half.

Display Name:
BC Duck

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1778832.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a mirepoix and pulsed it course for the cavity. Cleaned and stuffed the chicken and dried it. Took a quarter cup of fancy premade chicken rub and put into a gallon ziplock and coated the bird. 20 hours later put on a rack loosely tented at 250F for 2 hours in a casserole dish. Removed the tent and check the internal temp. Removed the foil and finished it off at 350. Removed the mirepoix and served. The leftovers got picked off the carcass and went into a Stove Top stuffing and chicken gravy mush for lunches. They baggie up and freeze nicely and thaw during the day to be microwaved at work.

I've tried several recipe's from this site and this is the 1st that I've rated! If I could give this 5000 stars I would!  Made this yesterday for Thanksgiving and it was TENDER, FLAVORFUL and downright DELICIOUS!!!

I did tweek the recipe a bit by adding lemon pepper, & doubling the pepper portions (we like a little kick).  I also took approx 2 tbsp's of yogurt butter and 2 tbsp's of honey butter (honey butter was an accident) and mixed with some of the spice mix and put under the skin of both chickens before rubbing spice mix as recommended in the recipe. Everything else I did as the recipe instructed.  It was OFF THE CHAIN!!!! Honey and I Loved it and I will CERTAINLY be cooking this again in the future!

text:
We loved the spices in this recipe. We have been trying various spice combos and haven't found them to be near as tasty. The only changes I made were to eliminate the white pepper (didn't have it and didn't miss it). I halved the amounts since I only made 1 chicken. I forgot to start the night before, so it only got a couple of hours seasoned in the fridge. I cooked it breast side done with carrots, celery and new potatoes for 3 hrs - it turned out great! Even my picky eater 7yo ate a leg and asked for more!! (Let me tell you that alone says volumes about this recipe!!!) We will definitely make it again.

text:
Good recipe. Like others, I found it too spicy & so did my boys, but my husband liked it a lot. It crisped up nicely, despite not wrapping it & leaving in the refrigerator for a while-- though next time I will do that because it will be even better. I also used only one bird, though I like the idea of cooking once and having two main dishes. I made this with saffron rice and broccoli. I did add butter to the top & spray with a butter spray toward the end if cooking because the spices were not getting "sticky". This step helped, and I'm certain I wouldn't have needed to had I refrigerated it. Very nice & easy "set it and forget it" recipe.

text:
So far I've made this three times this month! An easy way to make delicious chicken for multiple meals at a very low cost. I followed the recipe exactly and made two chickens each time for easy leftovers. It is truly fix and forget! Once done, I cut the remaining chicken in half with shears. Bones are easy to remove since the chicken is well done. The meat is really, really moist. I have rewarmed in the oven, wrapped in foil. I have also zapped in the microwave for several minutes on medium to warm up. Both work well. The same fresh rotisserie flavor remains. Pieces can be used in chicken salad. Tonight I'm using breast meat with a side of pasta. It's all good! The spice mixture is PERFECT. I made a large amount of that and now keep it handy in a rubbermaid container in the spice cupboard.  If you like wings, you won't believe how scrumptious they are with this recipe. Thanks for a winner!

text:
Made as directed. White meat was dry, dark was better, and it wasn't "sticky" as described. Flavors were not bad, but could have used more. There was a lot of juice in the bag before cooking. What I believe happens is that the salt pulls the juices out of the chicken. Given enough time, the chicken should reabsorb that (plus the seasonings) and make for a very moist bird (I've done this on turkey), but overnight standing just doesn't give it enough time.

text:
I figured we were on to something good when you see the number of total comments on this recipe but the outcome surpassed even our high hopes. Succulent, tender and flavorful cover the bases to describe this dish. We kept looking in the oven's window wondering if the chicken was going to cook or would we be ordering take out.  It was perfect. We made the rub just as detailed but now that we see how it works we could create varied rubs depending on taste. My only recommendation would be to know your oven's true temperature. Five or 10 degrees either way, especially too low, could make or break this recipe. Check ours once or twice a year and it makes a big difference with baking or slow cooking. Enjoy!

userID:
8980891
Display Name:
lilpug
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
17
favoritesCount:
270
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty good. I had only a small 2.5 pound chicken so I halved the spice/onion ingredients, and halved the salt again. Had to make some spice substitutions for what I had on hand but tried to stay close in taste: used red chili powder instead of paprika. Instead of onion powder, thyme, white pepper and cayenne, used Mrs Dash (orig) spice blend-has much of that stuff in it. Rubbed spice mix under breast skin & all on outside, onion inside. Marinated overnight in fridge. Roasted at 250F with oven probe thermometer in thigh. When thigh temp was 170F, checked temp inside lower breast, in middle of chicken and it was barely 140F. Chicken looked really dry and there were no juices in the pan at this point. Turned up heat to 350 and put back in oven until breast was 165-170. As heat went up, juices started bubbling out into the pan. I probably ended up overcooking the chicken (esp. legs) a bit, but it was still tender and moist, and as I cut it I dipped some of the white meat into the pan juices before serving so it really had that rotisserie taste, no gravy needed that way.  I removed the skin before serving. The skin was just dried and unappealing, not crispy/moist, but it did a good job keeping the meat moist while cooking. Next time I'd rub olive oil on the outside of the skin before cooking, to make it edible. The meat itself though was quite delicious and my DH declared it a success and even went back for seconds (unusual for him when it comes to baked or roasted chicken).

text:
Excellent recipe. I cooked mine in 1 hour and still turned out great. Marinated in rub for 2 hours. Baked at 400 degrees  Sprayed pan and tin foil wiith Pam cooking spray to avoid chicken from sticking. Placed chicken in pan and covered with tin foil for 30 mins. Removed from oven to baste then put back in oven for 15 more minutes. Finally I removed foil and basted chicken again.  broiled until skin was crispy on high or put on BBQ for a char broiled taste. Yummy!

text:
This was simply amazing.  I made the rub as directed.  I actually made a really large batch of it to keep on hand.  I only did one chicken, I stuffed it with an onion and garlic, and coated it all over with the rub, then tied it up so the legs and wings were tight.  Then I wrapped it tightly in saran and put it in the fridge for 5 hours.
Here's where I varied from the recipe, I actually cooked it on the rotisserie.  I maintained a heat of 325 on the bbq and cooked it for 2.5 hours.  It was perfect, flavourful and juicy.  Best Rotisserie chicken ever!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This chicken recipe is awesome,  I'm so glad I tried it. Everytime I make these chickens they come out so good  and everyone raves about them. The only thing I do different, is I put the chickens on a flat rack inside a large roasting pan and I pour 2 cans of beer into the pan (any type of beer works well). The beer makes such a great jus which you can use as is or make into a gravy. Also, I turn the heat up to 375 during the last hour of cooking so that the fat renders out of the skin and it becomes crispy and a bit charred, which I like....EXCELLENT!

Delicious!  I used a 6lb whole chicken.  I followed the recipe, only cutting back a bit on the salt and increasing the garlic and onion powder.  Also rubbed the chicken down with butter prior to rubbing in the seasoning.  I cooked it for 15 minutes at 375 and then for 4 hours at 250.  It turned out beautifully!  Drippings made an excellent gravy, and the meat was ridiculously moist!   Now, I have leftovers for chicken pot pie and I plan to use the carcass for stock!  Thank you!

userID:
3706201
Display Name:
MomMercer
isPro:

3

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fantastic! I used to boil my chickens when I wanted chicken for salad or other recipes, but now this is the way to go. It's so easy and the flavor is phenomenal! Then I've got a main meal prepared for that day and only have to de-bone the birds! I didn't have time to refrigerate overnight, just get them in the oven in time for dinner and it was still just a flavorful! A few things different that I do: I add more garlic powder, at least 1 tsp, used dried minced onion instead of powdered, and again, more of that, and used crushed dried thyme, not powder. I forgot to put onions inside the second time I made it, and there really wasn't much difference, so don't do that anymore. And a special thing I always do when making whole poultry (turkey too!) is to roast them breast side down. All the juices go into the breast keeping it so very moist. When I serve them, I put one on the platter breast side up, the other breast side down and we can pull off dark or white meat, whatever is your preference. I also baste the birds once or twice in the last couple of hours. This is a regular recipe at our house every two weeks or so... always need that meat for something, and it's a welcome, delicious meal, even for company. It looks like you've really worked hard! Awesome!!!

My family loved the recipe.  I had one 4 lb Young Purdue roaster. It was a little too salty.  The next time I will cut the salt in half.  Had enough pan drippings to make gravy with (2) TBLS of cornstarch.  I cooked the chicken on 300 for 1 1/2 hours then turned down to 250 for 2 1/2 more hours because I was in a hurry.   Otherwise...excellent my family loved it.  Definitely a keeper.  They ate the whole chicken.

Display Name:
Linda Burton Morgan

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I left out the white pepper because I didn't have any, but the seasoning for this chicken was wonderful and we loved the end product.  The chicken was tender and juicy.  I basted it once, mid-way.  I defatted the juice and made a delicious gravy with just a little cornstarch as there wasn't a need for additional seasoning.  What I liked about this recipe was the ease and simplicity in the preparation.  This recipe is a keeper!

An important additional note:  In my initial review, I failed to mention that I thought the original  recipe was much too salty.  I have since been preparing the seasoning with only 1 teaspoon of salt, rather than 4 teaspoons per the original recipe and it's quite adequate.  Another tip in the preparation is to place the chicken on plastic wrap, and rather than rub it with the seasoning, I prefer to sprinkle the seasoning mixture evenly over the entire chicken with a teaspoon, then I wrap it up tightly in the plastic wrap to marinate in the fridge, rather than rub the seasonings into the chicken with my fingers.  Rubbing it in causes 90% of the seasoning to end up on your hands and not on the chicken. My result, every time has been delicious chicken with moist and tender meat falling off the bone.

Display Name:
Brooke

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this on two separate occasions and both times it turned out pretty good.  The first time I mixed of the seasonings with softened butter and slathered it all over the chicken.  That turned out to be really messy and I probably would not do that again.  The next time I made this, I made it with two chicken quarters.  I placed the chicken in a 9X9 square pan and let it marinate overnight.  The following day I took the chicken out of the fridge and let it sit on the counter top for about 30 minutes.  I then baked it in the oven on 325F for 2 hours.  I didn't open the oven until after the 2 hrs.  Update 3: used a 4lb chicken.  I did make a few minor changes to the rub (halved the recipe): Instead of 1/4 tsp cayenne, I used 1/8 tsp and instead of 1/4 tsp of garlic powder, I used 1/2 tsp.  I marinated the chicken overnight and let it sit on the counter about 2hrs before putting in the oven the next day.  The rub was placed on and under the skin as well as in the cavity.  Cooked in oven at 250f for 1.5 hrs and then raised the temp to 325F and cooked for another hour or until the thigh reached an internal temp of 165-170F.

text:
Wonderful recipe! I omitted the paprika and white pepper that I didn't have on hand and used about a full teaspoon of garlic powder. Then rubbed the spices in and left bagged overnight. 
I was afraid of it drying out too much so about halfway through I basted the chicken and covered with lid. This retained the drippings which I then made gravy with. 
The only thing I will do differently is to try cutting the salt in half. The gravy was kind of salty, but good.
I will definately make this one again.

text:
DELICIOUS FLAVOR!! VERY GOOD RECIPE SUE ROGERS!! I used 1 whole 4 lb 15 oz bird. Rubbed bird ALL over with olive oil, some minced fresh garlic (that you get in a jar from the produce dept) & ALL the spices that was supposed to be for 2 birds. I rubbed it all under the skin also. I put 2 small pats UNSALTED butter under the skin. Basted 3 times. Excellent drippings. It's not too spicy, mellows out while cooking (I even added more cayenne). I used smoked paprika instead of the regular, which is what I use most of the time & used 1/2 the amont of salt (I used a combo of garlic salt & onion salt INSTEAD of PLAIN salt, which is what I use when cooking anyway). Next time I will take out at 4 hr (depends on your oven). Will make soup with carcass today. And I WILL DEFINITELY make this again. THANK YOU SUE!! ;o) UPDATE: I made chicken noodle soup with the leftovers & WOW the soup was AWESOME with all these seasonings that was used on the bird. NO LEFTOVERS at all!! Next time I make this I will remove ALL the skin & marinate a COUPLE of days & do in slow cooker. I will give an update on this after I make it. I will try this rub on a turkey too!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My son is a mashed potato lover and I made the Party Potatoes with this.  I asked him how he liked the potatoes and he said they're good but he loved the chicken better!  He said it was probably the best roast chicken he has had in a long time.  What I did was prepared it the night before around 7PM with the spices and left in fridge overnight.  When I got up to get ready for work, I set the oven on 170 degrees and put the chicken and potatoes in the oven and let them cook all day while I was at work.  I didn't get home until 7PM and had to turn the oven up to 350 for a half hour to get another 10 degrees of internal cooking and to get more of a glaze on the chicken and the crust over the potatoes.  Clean up was so easy because it fell off the bone and I placed the leftovers in a bowl since two of my sons weren't home.  My daughter loved it too but she's more the type that just eats when she likes something and you hear if it's bad.  My children are young adults not little children.  This is definitely a keeper and I'm so grateful to Allrecipes for storing my recipes otherwise I would never find this one again.  Thank you for sharing Sue Rogers!  :)

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Instead of two smaller birds I used a 8 Lb oven stuffer roaster. I did prepare the bird yesterday and it sat seasoned overnight. I tried 250F but using a remote internal thermometer was concerned that it would not be cooked in 5 hours. So I toyed with the temp and for the last half hour it was at 350F. It finally reached 165F internally after 5 and 1/2 hours.
The taste was exactly as advertised. It tasted identical to rotisserie chicken however was much moister. I did baste it frequently and since it made very few juices of its own I used the water I had boiled the neck, gizzard and liver in for the dog. Very yummy, although I found the skin a little too intense for my tastes (I usually like rotisserie chicken skin). The bird was moist and extremely flavorful...well worth the extra trouble/ And I have made additional seasoning mix to keep on hand.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yes the meat was falling of the bone, but I felt the meat was almost mushy in texture and had lost it's meaty feel.  Also a lot of juice came out of the bird in a 5 hour roasting and the low heat did not produce the crispy skin that high heat roasting does.  The rub is good and the 4 tsp of salt in effect "dry brined" the bird which always helps with flavor and tenderness.  The gravy was good probably due to so much of the juice being in the pan instead of in the bird.  I will stick with the traditional roasting methods.

text:
As with the other reviews, I wondering about the “sticky” part of the chicken’s name since it was neither sweet or sticky.  Maybe it is because the spices “stick” to the outside of the chicken? All I can say is who knows and who cares. This was amazing. Some reviews criticized the toughness/dryness of the chickens skin, but I actually preferred it since, we don’t eat the skin. Plus, it was so easy to peel off. The dark and white meat were tender and juicy, literally falling off the bone. So much better than any store bought chicken. I will say that next time; I will cut back on the salt, but otherwise….amazing. Also for the people that said it was tough or dry, make sure you have it on the correct temperature. Its 250 not 350. And like people, most ovens have their own personality, so your oven may be hotter than the temperature that you set it too. I love this recipe and will probably be a weekly/bimonthly staple on our menu at home and will be using the cooking method on my turkey this Thanksgiving. I cant wait!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, I did not like this at all. It was not sticky - I don't know why they even named it that.  I was looking for the famous “sticky chicken” recipe – this was NOT it.  It did not resemble any rotisserie chicken I ever got from a deli at all.  Like so many others I do not understand the rave reviews – it doesn’t deserve it AT ALL.  

My suggestions to salvage this recipe if you must use it   1) Cut down on the onion unless you LOVE onions!  2)  Don’t expect a sweet glazed chicken - it will be covered in VERY STRONG red powder. Nothing sweet or sticky about it!  3) Unless you ADORE strongly spiced chicken DO NOT use more regardless of what other reviewers say!  In fact, use less! MUCH LESS!!!!  You can always sprinkle on more before you eat it if you like.  4) Be ready to make a gravy from the pan drippings – after such a long bake the chicken is dry - you will need it!!

country:

text:
This really is a great recipe.  I've made it four times in a month, and it's great every time.  I honestly don't understand why so many people leave off the white pepper, saying "who has white pepper?"  I had to leave off the white pepper once because I ran out, and you can really taste the difference when it's gone.  I have made this recipe and slow-cooked it as directed.  It turned out moist and tender, but didn't get sticky.  I honestly didn't care.  The skin was super-crispy, and there were some beautiful juices on the bottom of my pan.  It was delicious even if it wasn't sticky.  I've also prepped this as directed in the recipe and baked it at a higher temp for a shorter time, and it still made a wonderful baked chicken.  I now keep a shaker of this mixture in my spice cabinet to sprinkle over whole chicken, chicken breasts, and even roast veggies!  I hate to be one of those people who changes the recipe and then rates it based on a changed recipe... but I omitted a portion of the salt.  I do this because the chickens available to me are plumped with saline-based broth and are slightly salty to begin with.  Try adding some veggies and potatoes to the pan for the last 40 minutes or so, and you'll have a really great dinner.  I also really love to get an extra meal out of this one, so I throw the carcass in a stockpot and make some delicious chicken stock or soup.  Don't forget to use the onion from the cavity as well for this one!  Outstanding recipe.  Thanks for sharing!

This was fantastic, and although I had to amend the recipe a bit because I didn't have all of the ingredients...........I still think i'm able to give this 5 stars:)  The flavor was even amazing on the "inside" of the chicken......it wasn't just the skin that had all of the flavor. text:
Wow!!  I have been making roasted chicken for over 15 years, but this is by far better than anything I've ever made!  I too eliminated the white pepper since I didn't have it on hand and increased the black pepper and garlic powder to full teaspoons.  I also only cooked one large chicken (5+ lbs.) but I made the full recipe of spice mix and reserved half for next time.  I cooked it for 5 hours and it was perfect - tender, juicy, and falling off the bone.  The gravy is fantastic!  I have made this twice now and can only say that I wish there was a recipe like this for a whole turkey.  TIP: If you aren't going to be home to put the chicken in the oven 5 hours before dinner time, use the delay timer on your oven (most have this feature).  I put the chicken in the roasting pan in the oven before I leave, set the timer to start the oven in the afternoon, and when I get home the chicken is done and the house smells great!

I made this recipe tonight and it was absolutely fabulous!  I always brine my chickens and turkeys in salted water overnight, and the next night I let the chicken marinate in the rub.  Hands down, this was the BEST roast chicken I have ever made.  The meat literally fell off the bones!!!  I have kidney disease and must watch my salt intake, so I relied on the brining process to provide the salt needed and used none in the rub.  Absolutely delicious!!!  Unbelievably good!!!  Thank you for a wonderful recipe that I will make every chance I get from now on!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So good! I didn't have any white pepper or dried thyme, but I did use poultry seasoning in place of that. Also cut the cayenne to about 1/4 tsp (just personal taste). I added some chopped celery to the chicken cavity along with the onion. Also rubbed some of the spice mix under the breast skin. I didn't get to marinate this for too long, about two hours, but it was still juicy and flavourful. Made gravy from the pan juices plus chicken broth and some flour. I plan on making a big batch of this to keep around! Although I will cut back on the salt a bit, was just a little too much for me. This recipe was SO good it made me want to eat more white meat! The breast was juicy and tender not dry. I basted the chicken with its own juices for the last hour. LOVED this. Next time I want to try mixing the spices with butter and smearing that all over the chicken. Thanks so much, this is a new family favourite!

I have made this a couple times now and everytime we have had company over and they love it.  I cook it rotisserie style on the BBQ (low heat) with a pan filled with a mixture of chicken broth and left over spices (from rub) underneath the chicken & baste about every 20 min. Comes out juicy and wonderful.

Scale to 96 servings; get a Mason jar and store the rest.  Works really well with turkey legs and the recipe is very forgiving on the time requirement.  In a pinch you could rub the poultry and cook right away, although the marinade time and slow roast definitely yields more flavor.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is the BEST roast chicken recipe I have tried yet! My only change is to reduce the salt, I use about 1-2 teaspoons, I found 4 too salty.  I love the chicken you can get at rotisserie restaurants but it can get pretty expensive. I make this in bulk on a weekend, separate the meat from the bones (bones I use for homemade stock), and put the meat into freezer bags to pull out on a weeknight when I need it. It makes delicious sandwiches and wraps. My favorite way is to fry the chicken in a little bit of olive oil until slightly crispy, top it with a little bit of garlic mayonnaise (minced garlic mixed into plain mayonnaise) and make a pita wrap out of it. Mimics a middle eastern sandwich I really like from a restaurant I went to once.

text:
I know I'm in the minority here, but I didn't care for this recipe.  I only cooked one chicken, but I checked the temp frequently to make sure it didn't overcook.  While the dark meat was nice and moist, the white meat was dry.  And the crispy skin is usually my favorite part, but it was beyond crispy and almost inedible because it was so leathery.  I'll stick to my standard of dry brining Zuni Cafe-style, and butterflying and roasting at a high temp.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just came out of oven and is resting.  Took a sneak sample and it is great.  Moist, juicy and tasty.  I made changes the same as many others suggested:  less salt, whole garlic in cavity with onion, rub olive oil on skin before putting spice mixture on, basting a few times, and MOST IMPORTANT check internal temperature after 3 hours.  My roaster was 5.25 lbs. and at 3 hours 20 minutes temperature was 165 at oven temp at 250.  I raised the heat to 500 degrees for 5 minutes to brown the skin evenly.  Looks pretty and tastes great.  This one is a keeper.

country:
None
text:
I thought this was awesome! I rubbed the spice mixture all over the chicken and under the skin, placed a quartered onion and a tablespoon of minced garlic as well as some salt in the cavity, wrapped it up twice and let it sit overnight.  The next day I roasted it in the pan. I gave it a 20 minute heat blast at 350 and basted it for the first hour.  Next time I probably will just let it sit at 250 for the entire four hours because the breast was a little dry. No need for gravy with this, it really tastes good enough and moist enough to eat on its own!

text:
I made this as is and loved the ease, cooking method, moistness and basic flavor. I gave this a 5 star, HOWEVER, I think this should have said "spicy" not "sticky". The amount of red, white and black peppers was too much for the kids and my husband. That being said, I will definitely make this again but will make adjustments to suit our taste. We still agreed it is a wonderful recipe. Just a note, if you have a Convection Oven, the (2) 4lb chickens I made took 2.5 hours on Convection Roast at 250 F. I will make adjustments in the future to meet our schedule, but good to know if that applies to you.

I admit that I have used hundreds of online recipes, both here at allrecipes as well as others, but never have I felt so strongly about the outcome to feel an absolute NEED to comment.  As some have suggested, I too added garlic to the onions in the cavity and ended up marinating 24+ hours. I only eat white meat, which as everyone knows, can often be quite dry.  This however is, BY FAR, the BEST chicken EVER!  It turned out so incredibly moist and flavorful-even the breast, that I will NEVER roast a chicken ANY other way! text:
This wonderful recipe has become a standard in my repertoire. If you're like me you buy sale meats in quantity, and it's not much more work to prep whole birds with spices before wrapping for the freezer. Then I just defrost and pop in the oven. One caveat: if left uncovered, the skin become crisp to the point of leatheriness, maybe because I often use fryers instead of roasters. But even fryers come out succulent after just 4 hours when covered while cooking.

I will never stray from this recipe! I only let them marinate for maybe 3 hrs, I am really looking foward to doing it over night as the recipe calls for. I notice alot of reviers skipping the onion in the cavity... put something in there! I think an aromatic would work fine, but the onion releases moisture into the breasts along with the flavor. I think my white meat was juicier than the dark! I put the chickens on top of whit potatos and carrots that I seasond liberally with minced onions, garlic, and s&P. Fantastic all in one, set it and forget recipe. I cannot wait to try out a chicken salad with the leftovers.

This chicken is so moist! It is wondeful.  I did change the spices slightly using what I had on hand.  In addition to the onion in the cavity, I added lemon wedges and fresh rosemary.  I also cooked with the breast down.  It was ready in a little over 4 hours.  I'm glad I did not cook it the full 5 hours.  It might not have been as moist.  I will certainly cook this again!  Thanks for the recipe Update:  I made this again and this time instead of the rosemary and lemon, I put a sliced fresh jalapeno (seeded) and some honey in the cavity.  It gave it a wonderful flavor.  It was not spicy at all.  I cooked one 4 lb chicken and it was done in 3 1/2 hours.

text:
Great Great chicken recipe.  very simple.  i made  using one six pound chicken so cut to a 6 serving recipe.  i did not have onion powder so i replaced it with some adobo.  

i rubbed the chicken with olive oil before rubbing the seasoning on and took the suggestion of putting some under the skin. I wrapped in the plastic wrap and left for 24hrs.  

 i cooked at 350 for a little over 2.5 hrs, each hour i used the "misto" to spray with a little olive oil.  It was falling off the bone and delicious. 

 To make the gravy i took the drippings added one cup of water and one chicken bulion cube.  boiled and stirred in corn starch.  GREAT!

text:
I have made this twice, and it got much better the second time. Marinating the chicken overnight is misguided. In addition to it being a pain to stuff the chicken in a plastic bag, most of the spices fell off. The second time, I rubbed the spices on right before baking, and the results were much better. I used a 6 lb chicken, halved the spices, and it took 3 hours in the oven. I rate this highly for ease and the good rub. It tasted pretty good. However, it wasn't spectacular, and not quite close to real rotisserie.

This is infinitely better than I expected it to be. I can't believe that I made it! I've never cooked a whole chicken before (I wasted more than a decade as a vegetarian). It is perfect and so juicy. I do suggest using a thermometer, not just timing 5 hours. I can't imagine what would have happened if I kept it in that long! My birds were done in 2 hours. Also, I don't have a roasting pan, so I cooked them on cooling racks over casseroles. Crispy skin on all sides!

This has become my 'go-to' recipe for chicken.  It simply doesnt fail.  I have done it exactly as the recipe says and marinated overnight, and cooked over low heat.  I have also done it by not marinating it at all, and cooking it at 375 when I was short on time.  Both ways comes out perfect and delicious. While this wasn't sticky like the recipe title suggested, it DID taste the most like rotisserie chicken I've ever tasted from an oven. The seasoning mix was wonderful - slightly spicy, for those who prefer mild foods I'd either play with the cayenne amounts or omit it all together. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This came out tender and juicy without all the trouble of dragging out the rotisserie. The spices are just about right. In reading some of the other reviews, while I wasn't surprised that some cooks cut the salt, I have to say that the only place I even tasted it was the pan juices and even then I wouldn't say that it was overly salty. The only change I made was to cover the chicken for a little while because for whatever reason the chicken began to dry out a little too much.  I haven't really figured that out because I was using an larger chicken...but it could have just been my oven, who knows. The next time that I make it I think I will try the roasting bag method another poster mentioned just because of my oven. Overall though, the family was quite pleased with the taste....there is none left! It was tasty...thanks for posting :)

Update: I just made this on the gas grill rotisserie for July 4th and it came out amazing!  My family just raved!  We had 4 meat selections and the only thing I have left is hamburgers...the chicken and pork tenderloin were the first to go.  From here on out, I will be marinating it and then putting it on the spit.

Wow! This did taste and look like a rotisserie style chicken, but only after I made some changes. 1. I cooked only one chicken at 325 for 1 and 1/2 hours. 2. I rubbed under and over the skin with butter. 3. I spritzed the chicken with Pam before baking. I did not change the rub mix, only cut in half. Loved this, and will definitely make again! The meat was so moist.

text:
I cooked this in my slow cooker and I skipped the overnight "marinating". I layered onions on the bottom of the crock and then I cooked it all day on the 8-hour setting. I transferred it to my oven under the broiler to crisp up the skin. It was super tender! When you take it out of the oven, cover it with foil and let it rest 15 minutes before you cut it and it will be sooo juicy. I didn't notice any lack of flavor from not seasoning it overnight. Served it with green bean casserole and sauteed squash. Great recipe.

text:
I give this 5 stars for taste, but only a 4 star rating due to it not matching the description.  The skin was very dry and not edible with no sticky glaze like a rotisserie style chiken.  Maybe basting would have helped, but who wants to do that all day.  I also caution on the time it takes to bake.  At 3 1/2 hours I checked it with an instant read thermometer, and pulled it out then.  Added one can of chicken broth and cornstarch to the drippings for some of the best gravy.  I recommend this recipe, just be aware what you will get is a very flavorful roasted chicken.

This is the best chicken recipe of EVER! The only changes I made were using cut up chicken pieces and after it marinated overnight I rubbed about 2 Tbsp of butter over the pieces. I baked it covered at 325 for 1 hour, then I uncovered it and raised the temp to 350 for about 40 minutes. This chicken turned out juicy, and the pan drippings were amazing over mashed potatoes. You have to try this recipe!

city:

country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe!  Well, our version of it!  While preparing the chicken, I discovered that I didn't have any paprika nor onion powder.  So, I substituted turmeric for the paprika and omitted the onion powder all together.  Oh my goodness was it good.  I also made some compound butter of the same spice mixture and slid it under the skin of the breast.  Since I also just made one bird, I cooked it at 300 as it was suggested for 2 hours 40 minutes and then I turned up the heat to 375 for the last 10 minutes to crisp up the skin (I also sprayed Pam on the skin before I sprinkled the spices on the bird).  Lastly, I added a celery stalk and a couple of cloves of smashed garlic to go with the onion inside the cavity.  We can't wait to try the recipe in its original form! :)

text:
This was my first time roasting a chicken and it turned out great! I used double the amount of spices except I kept the salt at 4 teaspoons. For someone who doesn't want it salty I would use even less salt, it was perfect for us but we like things salty. I roasted mine (I cooked 2 at once) exactly as instructed for 5 hours. I basted it once about an hour before it was done. There was NO need to add additional liquids as the chicken produced plenty. I used the juices to make a gravy that was phenomenal. It had a little kick to it...the best gravy I have ever had. 

This is a wonderful recipe and I will be using it again and again!! I paired this with the Oven Roasted Red Potatoes (Donna Lasater) and it was wonderful!

text:
WOW this chicken was excellent!!  I did a 5-lb whole chicken.  My oven only seems to go to one temp, 350, so we put it on the lower rack and basted every 30 minutes.  It took about 2 1/2 hours to reach 180 internal temp.  The pan drippings made a gravy that was the bee's knees let me tell you.  And the chicken was the best I have ever made of this type... now I want to make it again for next weekend!  I would say this would go really well with the bone-in chicken breasts too if you don't want to do a whole bird. Make sure you get the kind with skin though because the skin was so flavorful.  I cannot say enough about how fabulous this recipe is.  YUMMO

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Extremely flavourful marinade, which penetrates the flesh. The flavour is rather "herby", but in a good savoury way. Use 1 to 1 1/2 tsp salt per chicken, depending on size. The recipe didn't call for any fat, but I rub butter/olive oil all over the chicken (under the skin too). You can put two pats of butter under the skin on each side of the breast if roasting breast-side up. Also, cover the wing tips and leg bones with some foil for the first 2 hours to prevent burning.

text:
Delicious!!!!  And SO easy!  Only mistake I made was accidentally cooking them breast side down. DON'T do it, take the time to make sure you have the breasts up otherwise you end up with soggy skin on the breasts and nice, crispy, flavorful skin on the bottom!  Will make again and again and again. . .

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Alright, I did make a few changes. I added fresh rosemary, a few tablespoons of sliced butter and two boullion cubes to the inside of the bird.  I made my own seasoning mix, I used Cavenders Greek Saesoning (no one should be without this in their spice collection), poultry seasoning, onion and garlic powder and some cayanne.  I finished it off with some butter under the skin over the breast and drumsticks.  Probably not the healthiest bird, but OH MY GOD!  I gave this 5 stars because this is a great starting point for a PERFECT Chicken.  I used one 6lb bird and it only took a little over 4 hours to reach 180 degrees.  I turned the oven off and let it stay for about an hour until ready to eat.  This chicken was so tender it fell apart when we tried to cut it.  My husband has an aversion to chicken, (too much time in the Mid East and in the third world) but he raved about this.  I was left with a tremendous amount of liguid that I reduced for an excellent gravy with mashed potatoes.  I know this will be my method from now on.  The prep is pretty much the same as I used to do, but the low and slow cook time makes a huge difference.  Thanks Sue!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2612522.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is incredible!  The first time I made it I roasted it in the oven and everyone raved.  The second time I made it I roasted it in the gas grill and everyone nearly fell out of their chairs! I found that with my Weber grill having only the front and back burners on keeps the temp right at 250.  I didn't place it directly on the grill but had it in a roasting pan and set that on the grill.  Then I just closed the lid and forgot about it.  I basted it two or three times during cooking.  It only took a little over 4 hours to reach a 180-degree internal temp so be sure to check the temp occasionally after 4 hours so you don't overcook it. It was better than the rotisserie chickens we get at our grocery store.  Don't be afraid to try your own combination of herbs and seasonings either.  The key to this recipe is the cooking method.  It will come out fantastic no matter how you want to season it.  Thank you Sue!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the only way I will cook whole chickens from now on. I used all of the spice mixture on one 4-lb. chicken, and rubbed some of it under the skin. I put some red onion slices in the cavity instead of quartered onion because I had them leftover. As per an idea from a previous reviewer, I roasted it using the 'beer can' method. I poured half the beer into a square baking pan and stuffed the chicken onto the can of remaining beer, and stood it in the pan. I tented it with foil for the first 4 hours, and removed it for the last hour. I'm glad I cooked it this way because I couldn't believe how much grease had dripped down into the pan (sparing us the fat calories), yet the chicken was oh-so tender and flavorful all the way through.

text:
Fabulous! Fabulous! Fabulous!  I never ever roasted a whole chicken before and this was a great recipe for "testing the waters."  Going by past reviews, I doubled the recipe, as one batch is really only enough for one bird.  I also didn't let sit overnight because I made up my mind quickly to make it, but it was tasty all the same.  I had one bird for dinner, and the second one made sandwiches and salads during the week.  I did add a little water to the pan about 1/2 hour into cooking, and then basted it continually about every 20-30 minutes, which made it just beautiful.  I have since done a turkey breast with the same rub.  This one is definitely a keeper.  I have been recommending to everyone I know.  Thanks for a great recipe.  I don't think I'll ever do a whole chicken any other way.

text:
Even though I previously tried and rated this recipe,I tried it again replacing the onion with orange quarter. The flavor is incredible!! Also we prefer marinating it overnight, as it takes on more flavors, also when I rubbed the chicken with the seasonings, I tried to rub underneath the skin directly onto the meat. Whatever you decide to use inside the cavity, it sure will steam through you chicken during baking and provide a flavorful moist chicken. Our family of 6 loves this recipe!!! Thanks Sue!

Superb. Kids went back for seconds and thirds. I used one six lb. young rooster, marinated it 24 hours, halved the seasoning. Moist beyond belief, it cooked in convection oven in three hours. text:
This was absolutely delicious! I laughed at the person who said they could go to their local store and buy a rotisserie chicken for $3.99, I completely agree! However, I had a blast making my own rotisserie chicken at home. The only changes I made were, 1. I added a tablespoon or so of minced garlic inside the chicken along with the onion simply because my boyfriend and I love garlic. 2. Put pepper on the outside of the chickens prior to placing them in the oven, simply because we love pepper as well. 3. I took the advice from another rater and cooked the chickens breast side down for the first 2 1/2 hours. Definitely worth the effort if you like rotisserie chicken. I made a delicious chicken noodle soup the next day with the white meat (my BF does not like dark meat) and I snacked on the dark meat for the next 3 days. Thanks for sharing.

text:
This was excellent!!!! Wish I could give this more than 5 stars!!!! Followed directions as instructed...I did however did not have  White Pepper to add but it certainly was not missed. I did add extra garlic to the recipe  ( inside the chicken cavity w/ the lemon- **cut in halves ** and onion ). The chicken roaster was about 7 lbs so it was cooked longer  for obvious reasons. When it was done, the chicken literally fell off the bone, the bones of the cavity  - honest to God - slipped right out!!!!!!!  Hands down the best moist chicken ever made. This is how I cook my Pot Roasts...very slowly, never needing a knife...I never had problems cooking delicious tender chicken ( chicken is my husbands favorite-so I'm always cooking him chicken- but this hands down was even better than my own. Did not get as sticky like restaurants but pretty darn close. I'm sure the next time I make this I'll have more success with that....For I Am Definitely Making This Again!!!!! I highly recommend this for everyone to try this method of cooking their chicken!!! 
THANK YOU FOR SHARING THIS!!!! ??????????????
P.S FOR THE ONES WHO GAVE THIS A BAD REVIEW....I'M SORRY TO SAY THEY DID NOT FOLLOW THE RECIPE  EVEN THOUGH THEY SAID THEY DID AND CLAIMED IT WAS DRY AND NO FLAVOR etc...IF YOU HAD COOKED MEALS BEFORE IN YOUR OWN KITCHEN , THEN YOU KNOW HOW TO ADJUST THE TEMPERATURE OF YOUR OVEN - ( MINE TENDS TO RUN VERY HIGH...SO I USE A LOWER TEMPERATURE THEN SUGGESTED ON SOME RECIPES ) -  AND ADJUST THE SPI

text:
This chicken truly is fabulous! I did one chicken that was about 5 lbs. I mixed up the spices in a little dish and coated the chicken, even putting some under the skin on the breast sides. I double wrapped it in plastic wrap and refrigerated it overnight as per the instructions.  I   chose to use a 13x9 pan putting the chicken on one side on top of canning rings which I used to make a rack (4 wide mouth around 1 regular mouth size in the middle). On the other side of the pan I put potatoes and whole carrots. My chicken was done in the 5 hours and the potatoes and carrots were great. They were not overcooked at all. The chicken was moist, flavorful and practically melted in your mouth! Hubby loved it. The juice was delicious. I didn't make gravy but put it on the chicken as an au jus, but it really didn't need it. I plan to use the leftovers for soup with the pan drippings but I doubt I'll have any left after lunch today! Thanks Sue for this great recipe!

I made this for dinner tonight and it isn't as good as store rotisserie chicken...it's much, much BETTER!  I followed the recipe exactly and it was such a hit.  The skin was caramelized and the meat was fall-off-the-bone tender as oh so moist.  I used the rub from the recipe, and it was great.  I'm going to try a couple of different rubs I have in my recipe inventory like southwestern, oriental and Mexican for a variety of flavors.  The secret is in the roasting method...slow and  long.  It's the best method I've tried and I've tried many ways to prepare a chicken roast.  Try it, you won't regret it.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I would suggest not roasting a chicken at such a low heat for so long. Here is a response to a similar question on another cooking forum:

A few days ago I printed out a recipe from peacefulnightdove "BEST Slow-Roasted Chicken". It sounded wonderful but was to be roasted at 250 F (126 C) degrees for 5 hours. That sounded like a low temperature to me, so I emailed the County Nutritionist and Health Agent where I lived. Here is her reply: Good for you JoAnn to be suspicious! That is definitely outside the USDA guidelines, and yes bacteria may well be growing for quite a while in there. Poultry especially should not be done at less than 325 degrees. You could use the same spices and onions, increase the temp to 325 and decrease the time. Figure about 20 min per pound for the time. The safest way is to use a meat thermometer, final temp in the thigh should be 180 degrees.

text:
Could someone please weigh in on how to do this with a turkey? Cook all night or....? Adjust hours by weight compared to chicken? The chicken recipe was great and those having problems should check their oven temps to ensure an oven thermometer matches their oven setting. It is not uncommon for ovens to be inaccurate and at this low temperature, 275, it could matter a great deal if the oven temp read as 275 but was really 325 or more. .

Seriously. Let me explain. My man doesn't eat rotisserie chicken. He thinks its slimy. (Store bought, or Boston Market) He won't eat it and therefore Ive never made one. I have missed it the last two years of our relationship. So last night, I went to Harris Teeter and picked up one bird, since theres only two of us, I thought two birds would be too much. I used ALL of the seasoning on one 4 lb bird, I was praying it wouldnt be too much but my guy likes his food very seasoned so I figured itd be ok.. I popped it in the oven on 275 and cooked it for 3 hours. When my babe came home that night, the whole house smelt delicious. He was staring at the chicken with disdain... I said try some white meat, he ate it and lordddd it was all worth it!!!! Im making it AGAIN!! And the gravyyyy sooooo good!!!  I put about half a cap of gravy master into a small pot with the drippings, added a table spoon of corn starch mixed with water and oila! Delicious delicious gravy!!! thank you so much for this recipe!

text:
I am married to a beef loving husband, and have been trying to convert him into a chicken lover for 2 decades.  I've made this recipe several times following the most helpful reviews.  I've never marinated it for 24 hours , and it's always turned our delicious; it probably us more flavorful if marinated , I but you can't always plan ahead.  Today I added melted butter , approx 2 tablespoons, rubbing it under the skin of the breast and inside the cavity.   Then, I rubbed the breast, under the skin again and the cavity,  with the dry rub seasoning as per the directions .   I use a French style , cast iron cruset Iven roster I bought at Costco; it seals in the juices and nicely browns the bird also, baking at 250 degrees for 4 hours.  I truly think the French style oven roaster  makes it more flavorful.   This is the most delicious and juiciest chicken I've ever tasted.  My husband loves it !!!   It's such an easy and delicious meal, and is also beautiful enough for company, if you can find a large bird or cook 2 smaller birds.   You can't miss with this recipe !!!!

country:

text:
This chicken was so delicious and easy to make. I've been cooking for some time, but wanted to try my first whole chicken. To be honest, I was a little intimidated. It turned out amazing however. Fall off the bone delicious.

Since it was just my husband and I; I cut the recipe in half and made a single young free range chicken. I marinaded the chicken for almost a full 24 hours before placing it in the oven and the bake time was closer to just 4 hours, which was when it reached 179-180 internal temp almost to the minute. (It was just luck that I had checked the temp 10 minutes prior in anticipation with a faster cook time with a smaller chicken and realized it was almost done) If you plan to do the same, I highly recommend monitoring your bird to avoid drying it out. 

I also didn't have a roasting pan prior to making this, so I had to use baking dish and it turned out perfectly fine. I made sure to pour the juices over the chicken just prior to serving and it was divine.

text:
This is the best roast chicken I've ever made. I followed recipe exactly.  The chicken sat in frig with spices overnight and i cooked starting in the early afternoon.  I think it only took four hours to cook, so use a meat thermometer to avoid overcooking.   So good, so easy.  I'll be adding this one to regular rotation.

I think this was pretty close, as close as I have tried, with exception that it was incredibly salty. I had to rinse off the chicken in order to eat it, and even then we couldn't eat it. The 'inside' chicken was flavorful, and I would try this again but using 1/4 or 1/3 of the salt -- we can always add salt later if need be, but I dont think it will. Other than that, I'm a fan of the actual flavor.

text:
good spices..but easily adjustable for nay-sayers ;)  As for the complaints of too much salt, too dry etc, make sure you pay attention to how much the ingredient list is for.  For example this was for TWO 4 lb birds. Eight pounds of meat, so..just put on what you need.  I just roasted mine in a greased roasting pan like I would any other whole chicken.  COVERED at 350 for 1 hour, plus an additional 30 min. UNcovered so the skin will darken up.  easy and good

Display Name:
Dolly Bigelow

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1387149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this exactly as stated (minus the white pepper) and it was absolutely delicious! My Husband declared, "no one has ever made me a chicken this good!" The skin was crispy and the flavor was wonderful. The chicken was still juicy and moist although it had been in the oven for 5 hours. Slow is the way to go! 

I did make one change. The chickens were producing a lot of juice, so I drained that off 1.5 hours before the chicken was ready to come out of the oven. I was afraid that the bottoms of the chicken would get soggy if I left them in the pan with the chicken. That last hour and a half without excess juices really locked in the nice crispy crust!

P.S. I made a gravy with the pan juices and it was absolutely scrumptious! It was a tad salty, so if you plan on making a gravy with the juices I would suggest cutting the salt in the spice mixture to 2 or 3 tsp.

I have made this about 5 times now, and have recently eased up on the salt and cayenne a bit. Other than that, this recipe is a knock-out! I use this leftover meat for pot pie, chicken spaghetti, and delicious chicken salad. Situate your chicken on a rack so it's not sitting in the drippings, then use drippings to make an amazing gravy. This is a great recipe. There is only my wife and myself so I cut the recipe in half. Followed it to the letter.  In my oven the chicken was done in 4 hours. I will definitely make chicken this way again.
I served it with fresh cooked broccoli with a cheese sauce.

country:
None
text:
I make this chicken almost weekly.  It is bar far THEE best roasted whole chicken recipe!  My husband and sons and I love it!  I do not "marinate" it, (just never make the time) but it turns out great!  There is just the 4 of us so I only cook 1 chicken, so therefore I half the ingredients for the dry rub.  I shake the rub all over, inside & out, under the breast skin.  I use 1-2 onions in the cavity...I think that adds to the amount of juice/gravy at the end.  I always make it with mashed potatoes.  I usually end up boiling everything that's leftover to make chicken broth/stock.

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe at least a dozen times and shared it with everyone i could think of.  For the first few times i followed the exact recipe with the exception of the white pepper - something i just didn't have and never buy.  The last few times i have still followed the ingrediant list minus the white pepper, but only "marinated" the chickens for a couple of hours and then baked with a lid on at 350 for 1 1/2-2 hrs.  I started this short cut version when i forgot to take the ckns out in advance but still wanted the flavors.  Also i don't eat the skin so i don't mind that it tends to end up not crispy - trying to eat a bit healthier.  It works though the rub tends to sit a bit thick on the ckns, which is more than i like...but its worth it for the flavor!!

As expected, when you have a recipe that has this many positive reviews, it has got to be good. Kids LOVED it as did grownups. Two thoughts: Double the spices and use lots. When I make it again I will definitely cook this for about an hour less than the recipe indicated.

city:

country:
None
text:
Delicious! I followed the recipe exactly as stated accept I used a 7.15 bird instead of two small birds. I rubbed the chicken with the spices and coated two small onions with the left over seasoning and stuffed them inside the bird with 3 tbsp minced garlic. I wrapped in plastic wrap and let it marinate over night. I had the mr. Pop it in the oven around 2:30 and it was done by the time I got home at 6:45 (a little overdone. Meat thermometer read 180 but the chicken was not dry AT ALL). Like others, I added a slurry mix to the rendered juices with chicken stock and it made a fabulous gravy. I can't wait to make this again. Would be perfect for dinner when you have people visiting because the recipe is not very involved but soo delicious.

text:
I made this as written: marinated  over night and baked for the whole 5 hrs. Really really good, moist and flavorful. My man said "better than store bought" and it really was. I baked this in my Le Creuset Dutch oven (lid off) and let the chicken rest while I made the gravy (which was really good and spicy)  right in the pot. May start doing this every Sunday during the Winter as the left overs were super juicy and easily encorporated into other meals during the week. Thanks for the 5 hr roasting  idea. BTW this is NOT sticky...nothing to carmelize so if that's what you're wanting this isn't that.

text:
True rotisserie chicken taste!  I chose to use pieces, as another cook suggested.  I marinated them overnight and cooked them covered with foil for 1 hour at 300, then uncovered for 30 minutes.  They were a feast for the nose and eyes!  I attempted to make gravy and for the first time ever I was successful!  It was so incredibly easy and I didn't have to season it or anything.  We served it with mashed potatoes and asparagus.  Really, really good.  I have to agree with another comment that I think its the cooking method, not the seasonings that make all the difference.  My husband has already asked me to make it again!  Thanks for the amazing recipe!

text:
I made half of this seasoning blend for one 4+ lb. whole chicken.  I did, however, cut the salt back even further to 1/2 t.  I first put a thin coating of olive oil all over the outside of the chicken and then seasoned it inside and out using all of the seasoning.  We decided to grill this and at a much higher temperature than called for in this recipe.  We maintained a temperature of about 425 degrees and this was done in just about one hour.  So my 5-stars is for the seasoning blend only.  Very good!

text:
We LOVE this recipe!  My daughter gets excited when she knows we are roasting a chicken for several reasons.  It's delicious the night we cook it and then later I will pick off what's left and freeze it, the drippings and the striped carcass for soup later.  I boil the bones till they are powdery and then discard leaving behind a wonderful base.  She raves about it.  Make sure you let the spice rub marinate over night!  It makes a HUGE difference.  I once was in a hurry and it only got an hour, same daughter looked at me and said "It was OK....  it's normally awesome!!! What did we do wrong?!"  I've even tweaked it by adding some other spices before but nothing beats the original in my opinion.

text:
I will NEVER roast a chicken a different way.  As with some other folks, I don't always have white pepper, and often add minced garlic in the cavity.  That doesn't change the flavor of the chicken.  I personally believe drying the chicken and using it as a dry rub overnight makes a big difference, as does the slow roast.  I didn't have to adjust the temp to brown the outside...it was like a rotisserie...set it and forget it.  The smell is heavenly and my friends have all asked for the dry rub.  Have fun making Sunday dinner again!

I didn't have enough time to cook, so followed the advice of another review, and cooked a little higher (@450) for about 10 - 15 minutes, then dropped it down to 350 for a couple of hours, and it was perfectly cooked, and still very juicy.  Even my very picky 3 yr old gobbled it up with a "it's yummy!!!".  This blend of spices is incredible.  I already plan on using it for several other dishes.  It would make an awesome batch of wings. The only negative I have about this recipe is that it is too salty as is, and this is coming from a salt-aholic.  I'd recommend cutting the amount of salt in half.  You'll still get plenty of the flavor, without overdoing it.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4386724.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow This was excellent.  I did change the recipe a bit, as my ovens theromastat is off, so I did it in my slow cooker.  I took 4 large chicken breast with bone in.  Marinated overnight with the rub from this recipe.  Sliced red potatoes and lots of onion and put on the bottom of the cooker.  I added 1/2 cup of chicken broth, then laid the chicken breasts on top of that mixture,and set it on low for 5 1/2 hours.  Turned it once, and when it hit 180* if was done.  Took it out to cool, then strained the potatoes and onions in a small dish and put in the oven on a warm heat.  Took all of the broth and drippings from the cooker added some flour and wisked.  Pulled the chicken apart, and it was done perfect Spooned some of the gravy over the chicken and onion/potatoes. My hubby had two helpings and loved it.  For me I had a mixed green salad with avocado, grape tomatoes, homemade croutons, and a simple ceasar dressing from this recipe site.  Tossed it with the chicken and had a wonderful healthy dinner for me.

text:
I have seen others rave about this recipe for years, and I've never tried it. Blame it on being stuck in my ways, hooked on my old chicken recipe. Well, when my sons saw the old bird sitting in the fridge, they groaned, "Not chicken again!" So I decided I better change things up a bit. I tweaked the cooking method slightly, but I prepared the chicken with all the spices exactly as called for. Instead of roasting this in my oven, I placed it on a beer can filled with 6 oz of chicken broth and some spices and I roasted it on 50% power for 4 hours in my NuWave infrared oven. THIS WAS SO GOOD! It did come out just a tad spicy, but it was just the best flavor. Everyone loved it. The next day I boiled what was left of the carcass and made an amazing pot of chicken noodle of soup. I'm so glad I finally tried this one.

Absolutely Fabulous! I had a 7 1/2 lb. chicken so I only made one. I thought it would take longer than the recipe called for, but was done in 5 hours. I refrigerated it until dinner time, then microwaved for 5 minutes (in juice) then brushed the skin with melted butter and finished it off for 15 minutes in a 400 degree oven. This was SO much better than anything I could buy. Totally worth the little bit of planning and effort it took.

AMAZING! Oh, so good! My mods: I used 2-1/2 teaspoons salt, and I dredged four pats of butter in the spice mixture and pushed the spice-covered pats under the skin at various places over the breast and down into the thighs. This was, of course, in addition to rubbing the spice all over the bird. I did baste a little toward the end. The pan drippings were delicious in gravy, too. I used this same recipe for my thanksgiving turkey with adjusted times, etc. It was also fantastic!

text:
Seriously the best, most moist roast I've ever made.  I only one chicken but got a roasting chicken that weighed about 7lbs.  Cooked perfectly in about 3 1/2 hours.  Took it out at 175 degrees to avoided drying out.  Used the drippings to make gravy, the left over meat in a casserole and made chicken tortilla soup with the carcass, making this a 3 meal chicken!

country:
None
text:
I combined the seasoning part of this recipe (minus white pepper since I was out of it) to add as a chicken rub but combined it with the beer butt chicken recipe that I also found here. I rubbed my chicken with a little oil then put the rub to the chicken inside and out. I did not refriderate.  I put in on a half can of beer and baked in the oven on 350 degrees for three hours. The chicken was so moist and juicy, when it stuck therometer into chicken, juice was oozing out. My husband was eating it and  was already planning the next time we would cook it.  I also took the drippings and made brown gravy that I also found the video also on this website and my little boy raved about it since I usually use a packet.  I will be cooking this recipe again soon.

text:
I've made this 3 times now, and it's been delicious every time.  I've mostly followed the ingredients except for white pepper, which I don't have, and I cut the cayenne in half because we don't like spicy.  I keep meaning to follow the cooking directions exactly, but I never give myself enough time.  I end up cooking it in my dutch oven for 90 minutes at 400F.  I just cook one chicken (change servings to 4).  It turns out so moist and delicious, and I love the seasoning. Some day I vow to follow the cooking directions!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful spice mix and cooking method.  Yielded a tender, moist bird, which was extremely flavorful.  I did modify the spice mixture very slightly.  Halved the amount of salt by choice, and halved the amount of cayenne by necessity because we ran out. :)  I also cut a couple pats of butter and rolled them in the spice mixture and pushed them under the skin on the breast (one pat per side) so that some of the flavor would be sure to get under the skin.  I'm making this again for our dinner tonight, and I can't wait!

text:
I've had this recipe for years although I got mine from a church cook book.  Anyway, this is the only way to roast a whole chicken.  My family loves it!  The 250 degree oven and the spices are key!  Don't try to speed up the cooking time by having a hotter oven.  You'll love this cooked slowly and the house smells AMAZING.  Much, much better than a store bought rotisserie.  When you make two on a weekend, you have lots of extra chicken for other great recipes during the week.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I brined my 5lb single chicken with "Simple Chicken Brine" by Jay from this site for five hours (added garlic/onion powder and 4 bay leaves) Patted dry with paper towels then rubbed butter on skin and under where I could fit it. Used this recipe for the seasoning rub (reduced cayenne by half for health  reasons). Placed chicken atop cut-up potatoes, onion, 2 garlic cloves, baby carrots and zucchini drizzled with olive oil and salt/pepper. SOOOOOOOOOOO good!!! Will definitely use this seasoning mixture again!!!!

This was good. I made only two changes based on what was in my Pantry, i did not have any white pepper, (i looked at two different supermarkets, only becacause i have seen it in more and more recpies lately and am curious to see what or if their is a need for special pepper .) I also could not find my cayanne pepper, but i did have some dried ground Ancho Chile Powder. I also used I 6 lb chicken instead of two 
The flavor was great the thyme very faint, almost  an after taste. next time i may put in a little extra. Will make again.(with white pepper! If i can find the stuff.)

Unbelievably juicy, moist, and soft chicken. The onion in the cavity is the key, you can experiment with the spice rub (as I did a little) and still get great results if you place onion and/or garlic in the chicken's cavity. Mine cooked in 4 hrs 30 min. Will be making this often!

I used this recipe's amount of seasoning for a family pack of chicken legs so I omitted the fresh onion and because I try to cut down on sodium, I opted to reduce salt to 3 total tsp (1 tsp onion salt, 2 tsp season salt).  This recipe was fantastic!  The chicken was moist, tender and flavorful even after I took the skin off (once it was cooked).  I passed this recipe on to others and this will be my go-to recipe!  Thank you for posting this recipe Sue!

text:
This is the only way I'll bake my whole chicken.  The first time I tried this recipe, I followed it exactly and it was good.  I've tried different store seasons.  Barbeque and sweet rub, were the best.  With the BBQ, I stuffed the inside with a sweet apple instead of an onion.  They were both good with the overnight seasoning and slow cooking.  The leftover makes a great soup.  My boys request this for their birthday and Christmas dinner.

text:
I used this recipe on some chicken drumsticks I had laying around and it was GREAT!!!! I cut the recipe in the half and excluded the onions and white pepper. I added 2 tablespoons on brown sugar and made a dry rub out of it. I didn't have time to marinate them so I put them in the oven for 30mins on 375. They came out crisp and with a spicy sweet flavor. I do think next time I will use less spice seeing as I had to add brown sugar to tame the recipe and it still had a kick to it, but its definitely worth the try.

text:
I'm saddened that I can only give this 2 stars.  One for the spices, one for the gravy it produces.  I read most of the reviews and before I embarked on the 5-hr journey for my 4-lb bird, I fiddled with my oven to make sure the internal temp was 250-degrees.  Still, the bird was dry.  I should have checked it, I know.  My entire family asked me to keep the spice mixture, but continue to roast chickens the way I always had.  They were rabid over the gravy, though (made with pan drippings, chicken broth and cornstarch).

Wonderful! I halved the recipe and it was plenty.  Instead of a whole chicken you can use chicken pieces.  I rubbed the outside of the chicken (legs and thighs are my favorite) with olive oil and then sprinkled in the spice mixture all over.  Then I popped them in the oven at 415 degrees for 35 minutes total, turning over at the 15 minute mark.  They turned out delicious!  I will definitely use this spice mixture again, maybe on pork chops next time!

region:
