country:
None
text:
Good, but WAY too salty.  And I love salty food.  I'll cut the salt by half next time.  Mine was also a little overcooked after only 4 hours, and I was actually using a 6-pounder.  I guess you really need to keep a close eye on it, and take it out as soon as it reaches 170 degrees.  As I'm now reading through some of the reviews, I see that someone suggested cooking it breast down for the first 3 hours and then flipping it, which apparently helps keep the breast moist?  Never heard of this, but will try it next time.  Overall, this was worth trying again with half the salt and a closer eye on the temperature.

text:
Excellent! I've made this three times in three different ways and it's been amazing each time. I think I've found perfection this last time though. I didn't let it sit overnight but it still came out wonderfully. Since I was only making one chicken  I halved the herbs and spices but I creamed them with a stick of butter. I seperated the skin from the meat and spread the butter on the meat over the breasts, drums, wings etc. I still spread it on the skin and inside the cavity. Baked covered at 375 for 75 mins and it was falling off the bone and extremely flavorful. Thanks for the wonderful recipe.

text:
OMG, Amazing!!  I'm not the best cook, but with this recipe I think I can fool people.  It was very simple and the results were outstanding.  I did not have a whole chicken, I used a bone-in chicken breast, split in two.  Because of this, it only took 3 1/2 hours to be fully cooked.  The only change I made to the recipe was use only 1/4 tsp of cayenne powder and 1 whole teaspoon of garlic powder.  This is the best chicken I have ever made!!

country:
None
text:
This RECIPE is amazing... My wife & I personally think it's better than the store bought rotisserie chickens. However, I did make some a few changes. I used an actual rotisserie via a convection oven instead of roasting it. I coated the outside with olive oil before applying the rub & left out the 2 onions. For the rub I upped the garlic to a full teaspoon; replaced the cayenne pepper with ground red pepper, added 1/2 tsp. of celery salt, & added 1/2 tsp. of ground cumin. Cooked a 5.25 lb bird at 400 degrees for 2 hrs.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is our standard for roast chicken now.  It is delicious!  I enjoy that I can do all the work when my energy levels are still up, and I don't have to be working hard around dinner time.  I usually brine the chicken overnight in salt water and season it right before roasting.  I have a low rack that fits my roasting pan, and it works beautifully.  Sometimes I'll throw red potatoes and carrots in the pan.  The drippings make an excellent gravy thickened in a roux.  We use the extra chicken for many things, and always make stock out of the bones--a delicious stock.  Thanks for a great recipe, a definite keeper!

text:
This recipe is a keeper! I 1/2 all the dry ingredients, and use one Pick-o-chick cut up chicken. I place it in a Corninware casserole dish with sliced onions, covered, in the fridge 5 hours or overnight. You can roast it with the lid (extra juicy) or with it off.  For 1 cut-up chicken, decrease roasting time by 1/2 hour.

To me this was ok. I was a little disappointed after the rave reviews. It was nothing like the rotisserie chickens we are use to eating.  The seasoning smelled great at first, but got to be a little strong after a while ( which is surprising because I love seasoning!!).  I cooked to a temp of 170.  Breasts were done perfectly, but legs were over done.  I did consider covering them with foil for a while, but decided to stick strictly to directions to make sure it turned out just as it should.

text:
I didn't want to bother with a whole chicken, so I bought thighs and drumsticks. I baked it at 300 uncovered for about 2 hrs. I basted the chicken twice, and broiled for about 3-4 min to get browner. I left the skin on. It didn't get quite as crispy as I wanted, next time I may increase the heat. But the chicken was really moist and delicious. And I used the extra juices for gravy. Just added a little salt and pepper, heavy cream, and flour to the drippings and onions that had been marinated and baked with the chicken. The gravy was delicious and really added to the already delicious chicken. I'll def. make again.

text:
This recipe is so DELICIOUS!  I have made this... probably 5-6 times now!  I am a working wife, so I don't have hours and hours to dedicate to cooking, so I actually make this at 400(F) degrees for about 1 hour and 45 minutes (basting every 30 minutes). I temp the bird at about 1 hour and 15 minutes to see progress.  I made this last night and the husband was baby sitting it and actually added chicken broth because it was too dry in the pan.  The seasonings are delicious the way the recipe calls, but I always add more than needed.    I serve with mashed potatoes and boiled asparagus - yum!  I keep one of the birds for the next day chicken sandwiches (which I cut off the meat from the refrigerated bird, and heat it in the microwave, throw it on to a sandwich with a delicious slice of cheese --- left overs are amazing!) .

text:
This was great!  I did as directed except I used less salt and I made the run into a paste w/ a little olive oil and schmeered the birds.  I also bought 2 7 lb. chickens so we would have some leftovers.  So, I ended up roasting them for 9 hours and they were wonderful.  I am glad I cut the salt because I think they were just a tad salty (for my own taste, so I'll cut a bit more) but, not so much so that they were not good.  The chicken was moist and tender.  I will be using this recipe over and over again. 
I also chopped some potatoes and carrots and added those about halfway through and they got the flavor of the drippings and were amazing.  I actually had to stop my son from eating all the potatoes!  And, as stated more than once the drippings make a delicious gravy.

country:
None
text:
Okay, this is a FABULOUS roasted chicken recipe!  I used one 5 1/2 pound roaster and thought that the spice recipe made just a little over enough for that one chicken.  I quartered one unpeeled white onion and halved one leftover garlic head and stuffed them both into the cavity.  I did let my chicken marinate overnight and probably won't ever change that.  Chicken was roasted for 4 hours on 250 (no basting at all), then I just turned the oven off as we had a party to go to.  Came back a couple hours later and thought my chicken was probably mummified.  But once I cut through that crispy skin, the most beautifully moist and flavorful chicken - EVER - came forth.  Oh my.  This is such a wonderful recipe that I'm planning on blogging about it.  Thank you Sue!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was quite possibly the best chicken (and was hands-down the best gravy) I have ever made. I followed the recipe exactly, did not baste the birds at all, and they came out moist, tender, and flavorful. As other reviewers have said, the chickens literally fell apart when we transferred them to a cutting board! Just as well, since we didn't know how to carve a bird properly. =)

The roasting pan was nearly full to the brim with drippings, so I could not resist making gravy. I made a roux with a couple of tablespoons of flour and about a quarter cup of the drippings, then added the rest of the drippings. Absolutely amazing! 

I will be making this again and again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
"This is the BEST chicken, Mom!" was the review I received from my family after making this recipe. For a 8lb chicken I doubled the recipe except for the salt (4 tsp Kosher salt) and the Cayenne pepper (3/4 tsp) - my kids don't like things too spicy. I started the cooking temp at 400 for the first 30 minutes then decreased the temp to 275 for the remaining 3 hours. I also basted after the temp change and every hour after that. I found that during cooking I had to add some chicken stock to the bottom of the pan to get enough drippings to make a lot of gravy - the gravy is fantastic! Just used a butter/flour base and whisked in the drippings. This chicken is the most tender and juicy I have ever made at home. At the request of my husband and kids, I have made this chicken four more times since my initial attempt. Thanks for a great recipe!!

city:

country:
None
text:
I have to admit something.  In all my years of cooking I've never roasted a bird. Turkey or chicken.  I've just always lived close enough to friends or family to have family holiday dinners, and somehow, I never got bird duty.  Of course I helped my mom growing up, but never on my own.  We loved this!  It was sooo tasty and moist and delicious, and we'll be eating on it for the whole week.  The dark meat was absolutely to die for, and the white meat stayed moist, although not nearly as flavorful.  But we'll use that for soups and other things and just eat the dark meat plain.  I couldn't stop picking pieces off, and I nearly couldn't move the chicken onto a cutting board because it just about fell apart in my hands.  I'll use this recipe over and over.  Make homemade chicken stock from the carcass and nothing goes to waste.  There's a way to stretch your $5... :)  I used one 7 lb chicken instead of 2, but used the full spice rub.  Thank you thank you my fear of bird roasting is officially conquered!

None
text:
If you don't have white pepper don't use it but for those who have never used it it's completely different than your usual black pepper.  If you do any cajun cooking you'll want to keep white pepper in your cabinet.  It adds a depth to your spicy dishes that surprises.  Anyway, LOVE this recipe, the whole family does.  I haven't had a chance to refrigerate the bird for 24 hours but it still comes out amazing.  I have a compact rotisserie so 2 hour cook time.

AMAZING!!!
This is soooo unbelievably good! Even my 9 month old and 3 year old gobbled it up!
I didn't have have cayenne pepper so I substituted with red pepper flakes for a kick
I also did not cover and refrigerate overnight, so it will probably be even better next time!
I only had 1 chicken, but I still used the same amount of spices and rubbed over the skin and underneath the skin as well..next time I'll use less salt
I didn't have an onion, so I sliced up an apple to put inside the chicken to keep it nice and moist.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
FANTASTIC chicken recipe!  I followed as written, except for the fact that I didn't have time to marinate.  I also increased the garlic power and replaced white pepper with a smaller amount of freshly ground black pepper.  I made sure to taste the rub to make sure that it was good for my palate before seasoning the bird.  In additon to rubbing the seasoning mix on the outside of the bird, I mixed a few tbls of the rub with softened butter, and rubbed that underneath the skin of the the chicken.  I seasoned the chicken liberally  and had it in the oven within an hour, and it was still fan-flippin-tastic!  I was worried because at about 2.5 hours the chicken still looked a bit pale and anemic but it carmelized beatifully and had an amazing flavor, sooooo tender after the 5 hour slow roast.

Wow, this was fabulous! My first attempt at a full roasted chicken (I usually make chicken breasts), and it was delicious and easy. I made a few updates based on other reviews: Only 2t salt, 1t pepper, and I added 2 T minced garlic to the cavity with the onion. I was going to make the gravy, but it doesn't need it at all! I used only one 5 1/2 pound chicken, and it was done in about 4 hours @ 250 degrees. Highly recommended!

userID:
4589372
Display Name:
Jenn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mmmm so good! I've cooked this recipe TO SERVE 4 PEOPLE a few times now, and have made a few adjustments to suit our needs/ tastes:  1)omit paprika and cayenne pepper as they can burn- there's still enough spice with the white and black  2)a 3.5 lb chicken only needs 1.25 tsp salt  3)marinate- as mentioned in other reviews- for at least 5 hours- it does make a huge difference :)  4)use a completely defrosted chicken  5) dice and saute large onion with olive oil and minced garlic clove, and let cool before stuffing into cavity (otherwise onion may not cook through and sauteing gives a better flavour)  6) add 2 cups of water to the bottom of the roasting pan- prevents splattering/ burning/ smoking and may need some replenishing every hour or so  7)my oven just doesn't do low temps well so roast for 2.5 hours at 150 degreeC  8) to make onion gravy: pour juices into small sauce pan and about half of the onions from the chicken- dissolve 1 tsp-1tblsp flour/cornstarch in water and add- bring to boil and then simmer for about a minute or less- you may need to add a bit of water/ salt/ pepper  Thanks Sue Rogers for this great recipe!!!

text:
If I could give this 10 stars, I would! I love rotisserie chickens, but this was 10 times better than any other chicken I've ever eaten.  In the words of my 5 year old son, "it's perfect!".  I followed the directions except used fresh minced garlic cloves inside and outside the chicken, and omitted the paprika and white pepper (since I didn't have those on hand).  The skin was crisp and golden, the meat was beyond tender and so moist.  I bought a bird with the little thermometer already in it and cooked at 250 until it popped up (right around the 4.5 hour mark).  I used the drippings as is over mashed potatoes and it was to die for :) So easy too- this will definately go into our regular dinner rotation!

text:
Well.....I felt this was more 3.5 stars but that's not an option in here.  I followed the recipe to a T... even let it sit 24 hrs wrapped up with the rub on it.  The chicken was INDEED cooked to perfection, and it did fall off the bone (meat was very moist).  However, the rub flavor is not present all the way through the meat.  It's on the skin only. Yes...  it was good...but was it just like store bought rotisserie chicken?  No...it wasn't..not in my opinion.  I did enjoy the long  term roasting at 250°!  Took it out at 170° - covered it in aluminum foil and let it rest 15 min.  DONE TO PERFECTION.  I will probably roast all whole chickens at this time/temp from now on, but I have still not found my PERFECT RUB.

text:
I was skeptical of the temperature and cooking time, but it worked! I rubbed it down with butter and halved the recipe for one chicken. After the first 2 hours it looked hopeless. But keep turning and basting once the juices start collecting in the pan. The meat fell off the bone and cleanup was simple since nothing burned onto the pan due to the low cooking temperature. Mix some of the rub into some butter and stuff it between the skin and meat. Then sprinkle the rest of the rub over the chicken. Use a thermometer to test doness.

xconfuzzledonex

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Didn't follow this *quite* to a T, but I didn't have all the ingredients on hand:  I one and a halfed the spices since I was working with 2 five pound chickens instead of 2 four pound chickens. I had no onion powder, and was low on garlic powder, so I grated a few cloves of garlic and rubbed them all over the chicken. Also, before roasting, I put a few pats of butter underneath the skin to make it slightly self basting.  Even after overcooking the bird slightly at a higher temperature this came out great. (At 350 for just shy of 2 hours, 2 5lb birds came out at about 190 degrees in a crowded oven. o_O) The meat was juicy and tender, and the pan drippings made an excellent white gravy. (If you're going to make a gravy from the drippings, note that you probably won't need salt in it--what runs off the birds will be plenty.) Will definitely make again!

I made this last night for dinner and it as good as everyone says, and so easy.  I saved the drippings, cooled in fridge, and removed the fat.  I used the gelled broth in a butter bean soup today as a flavor enhancer.  It tasted really great. I think you could use this in any soup to enhance the flavor.

text:
I'm not a big chicken fan, but I do like the rotisserie chickens that you get at the super markets and I have family and friends that like it.  Since I live alone, I decided to do chicken breasts.  I let one marinate for 24 hours and froze the rest (with the seasonings).  I'M IN LOVE WITH THIS RECIPE!!!  I will never ever make anything but this recipe for my guests.  The breast was moist, tender, I could cut it with a fork.  The skin was just perfect.  I did put some seasoning under the skin and quarter an onion (1/4) and put the breast on top of it.  It seems other people's chicken always taste raw to me so I have always avoided eating it on a regular basis and didn't like the taste.  I am a TOTAL CONVERT!!  If chicken can taste this good.  I can't hardly wait to have guests over.  Thank you for the recipe.

text:
This was by far the best chicken I've ever had. I only made tiny changes - I used two cloves of fresh minced garlic (as I didn't have garlic salt) and omitted the onion salt (I didn't have that either). I cooked it slowly for about 3 hours then we got hungry so I drove up the temperature in the oven until the bird was cooked, about 30 minutes later. The gravy was delicious and each bite of turkey we took we both groaned in pleasure. This is a fabulous recipe! Thanks for posting!!

text:
This is by far the best way to roast chicken! The meat is fall-off-the-bone tender and the flavor is great with just a hint of heat. I would recommend putting your chicken in the pan breast side up since the skin turns out better that way. I didn't realize the recipe calls for two chickens until after hubby had put all of the spice on one chicken. We rolled with it and ended up loving it. I would do it that way again. I did cut back the salt to just 1.5 t due to other reviews stating it was too salty. Try it - you won't be disappointed!

This was fantastic. Made as directed using 1 4lb bird and baking at 250 for 4hrs. text:
I follow the recipe exactly except for omitting the cayenne pepper, but the next day I simply didn't have enough time to leave it in the oven for several hours so I butterflied the chicken (following some web videos) and then roasted it above potatoes for 45 minutes at 475 and put a foil tent over it for 15 minutes after I pulled it from the oven.  Delicious!!  The breast was slightly more cooked than the thighs, but still fairly moist.  The thighs were pretty close to heavenly.  I also put the potatoes back in the oven for crispiness and my husband loved them.

country:

text:
i have made this twice and it has become a regular weekly meal. i use one chicken but the same amount of spices. add garlic to the onion in the cavity and let it sit overnight. i used butter the first time under the skin, and basted -- DO NOT do so. it doesn't need it at all. i add some chicken broth -- first time i basted, the second time i didn't, and it was even better when i didn't. i also added carrots and potatoes the first itme, but found it was easier to prepare them seperately. cooked the whole 5 hours on 250 and it is wonderful. we have chicken the first night, chicken sandwiches the next day, and then a big pot of chicken soup using the bones and meat left from night one. wonderful recipe!

text:
this is by far the best rotisserie chicken i have ever had, I have made this twice already!! The first time I stuck to the exact spice measurements and it was fantastic but just a little bit spicy for our tastes so this time I cut the white pepper and cayenne pepper to 1/4 tsp each and it came out perfect!! I only had 1 6-pound roaster and had to put it in the oven on my lunch break so I couldn't take it out at the 5 hours suggested so I knocked the temp down to 225 degrees and took it out when I got home from work after about 6 hours...boy does the slow-roasting make a difference! The meat was so tender and juicy, and what flavor...YUMMM!! my boyfriend is VERY picky and never gets too excited about meals but he actually called me at work to tell me how good it was the next day as leftover sandwiches! thanks for the fab recipe!

text:
This was pretty good chicken.  The taste gets five stars from me but the chicken was relatively dry through the breasts.  Normally I brine birds through the winter when I can leave them outside overnight.  This is the first chicken I've done since and it made a HUGE difference.  Will definitely use this combination of spices again when I can perfect the method.  I also made sure to baste it about once an hour or so because when I checked in after an hour it looked deathly dry even with the butter I'd slipped under the skin.  Eating the wings with my fingers I definitely found it sticky, but that may have been due to my basting.

933856
Display Name:
JARRIE

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/926498.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Well this was certainly an adventure for me, which is not at all due to the recipe. After failing to properly thaw my chicken (I used 1 5 lb chicken & resized for 5 servings) I found myself digging frozen chicken parts out of my chicken which is SO not fun. If I hadn't been on a schedule I'd have put the thing back in the fridge and let it thaw one more day. Since I had no time though, I filled a pot with hot water, put my still store-shrink-wrapped chicken in, and thawed it that way. (You have to change the water every half hour and turn your chicken side up and side down repeatedly else you'll have a half-frozen chicken that won't cook right. This method WILL work but honestly..if you have time...just put it back in the fridge for another day.) That aside, I made this recipe as noted except for exchanging white pepper for yet more black pepper. Also I removed the onions before I cooked it--but now I think I was supposed to leave them in. It tastes fine without them, but I'm pretty sure it'd have been even better with onion juices dripping into my roasting pan. I added carrots the last half-hour as I find they improve the flavor of the drippings. Last but not least, I roasted my chicken upside down. This was by accident really, and I have no idea if it contributed to the moistness of this chicken or not, but it made a terrific April Fool's day joke when my husband carved the bird and only found dark back meat!

I used the amount of spices on the recipe and a whole 5 lb. chicken.  Typically, my husband is not a fan of chicken. However, he loved this one! Moist and tasty. Even the breast were moist. Be sure to use a meat thermometer to check this. When it reads 170° it is ready to take out of the oven. Easy, easy, easy.

Very, very good.Used two 4 lb chickens. I went exactly by the recipe except I only used 2 1/2 tsp. of salt. Rubbed and stuck in fridge for about 3 hours. Mine were done in 4 1/2 hours and I basted once about 2/3 into cooking. The taste was excellent and my grandchildren loved it!! I'm going to try and freeze ahead and throw it in the crockpot as one reviewer suggested. I liked having one chicken for dinner and another already made for use during the week. I will make again.

text:
I baked it 250F, 4.0LB chicken with the skin on for 3hours exactly. and it came out so deliciously tasty and juicy. I love it so much. It was my first time making the chicken and I loved the juiciness and the flavor of the meat. My friend who is a cook also loved the flavor. I didn't eat much of the skin, but I'd say that if you like the skin, you may want to bake it on a higher temp for 30 min or so for a more crispy taste of the skin. I don't eat the chicken skin so it didn't matter to me that much. I love this recipe and so did my friends. I didn't alter the recipe. I skipped onion power and white pepper because I didn't have them, otherwise I stuck to the original recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best chicken recipe I have ever made!  I used one 5 pound chicken instead of two.  I used all of the spices called for, except I did not have white pepper.  I just used extra black.  I melted a stick of butter in a small sauce pan and then added the spices.  This made a thick "sauce" that clung to the chicken (I spread it on with a pastry brush).  I also stuffed the chicken with lots of chopped garlic and a big onion, cut into rings. I then stuck the chicken in the fridge for about 5 hours.  The result is an amazing, moist, flavorful chicken that smells great while cooking!

text:
With all the wonderful reviews I couldn't resist trying this.   I only used one chicken but used rub recipe for two and used it all.  Time being an issue, I only let the rubbed down bird sit in the fridge for about four hours.  I did put some water in the bottom of my roaster and I did baste three time during the 4 hours the bird roasted, I also flipped the bird at one point (bird was on a roasting rack).  I was afraid this would be dry as I used a fryer (bird) but this was juicy and delicious. My hubby is not a big chicken fan but he ate this up.  Wonderful recipe which I will use again and again but will make 2 next time so we have lots of leftovers. I would double the rub recipe for two birds. It really doesn't get any easier than this!

text:
We love this recipe.  I have been making it for years-a family favorite.  I have recently been using thighs and legs with the same seasoning and baking it for 3 hours at 250. Turning once or twice. So very moist but crunchy skin.  Great for parties/picnics.  Everyone begs for this recipe.  With leftovers I make Sticky chicken soup because all the spices give it a unique flavor than your regular chicken soup. Be prepared to make a lot of thighs and legs because they get eaten so fast.  We were not dark meat fans until I tried making this for a party. Try it.  It's the best!!!!!!!!!!

None
text:
Best roast chicken recipe ever!  I used a 5.7 lb roaster (instead of the two 4 lb ones specified in the recipe).  Cut the salt down to 1 tsp (could have cut it down further), and used 2 Tbs of Cajun's Choice Creole Seasoning along with thyme, paprika, black pepper and cayenne.  Put 3 garlic cloves through the garlic press and first rubbed the garlic on the dried chicken, then rubbed the dry spice mixture, put it in a plastic bag and let it sit in the fridge overnight. Put the chicken in the roasting pan (half an onion and half a stalk of celery in the cavity) and drizzled it with 2 Tbs of melted butter.  Followed the rest of the directions, although I let it cook an extra hour because of the larger size of the chicken.  Served the chicken with the cranberry chutney recipe from the Colorado Cache cookbook - totally yumsville.  Will definitely make this recipe again.

text:
My Oh My!!!  VERY good!!  It did take a little foresight.  I made the spice mix a few days before just to have that ready when I got around to doing this.  Used 3 large split breasts instead of whole chickens just because that's what I had.  Early in the morning, I rinsed the chickens, patted them dry, then put them back in the fridge to finish drying out so that I would get a nice crisp skin.  After about an hour, I put them in a large freezer bag with the spice mix and got the rub on them that way - I did not bother with the onions.  I popped them back into the fridge to marinade for a good 6 hours.  Then I cooked them at 300 for 2 hours.  Yummy!!!  The only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is because I think the spice mix is a little salty.  Next time I think if I use a little less salt, it will be perfect!

text:
THANK YOU so much Sue Rogers for sharing this incredibly EASY and flavourful recipe!!  I did not marinate the chicken overnight since I didn't have enough time but it was still THE most melt-in-your-mouth delicious chicken ever!  To the rub ingredients I added around 1/2 teaspon ground ginger and decreased the salt by half the amount specified.  In each bird cavity I added 1 onion, quartered, 4 garlic cloves, chopped, and chopped pimento peppers (to taste).  I added some washed, new (medium sized) potatoes at the begining of the roast time.  An hour before the roast was finished I added some baby carrots. My son who prefers not to eat ANY type of meat couldn't help but to "sample" the chicken again and again even before it was on the table! This will become one of my "signature" dishes. THANK YOU SUE!

text:
This never disappoints. I have made this many times now with the following observations: I no longer use all the spices, just salt and white & black pepper to enable the flavor of the chicken to really shine through. Convection speeds up cooking--a 4-pounder is done in 3 hours at 250. I always use this recipe (rather than braising or simmering) when I need cooked chicken for other recipes like chicken salad. Cooked this way, the chicken is super easy to pick.

Made this on a lazy weekend.  Put in the oven at noon and forgot all about it. text:
I have made this many times.  I usually brine my chicken first for about an hour in 1/2 cup kosher salt to 2 quart water.

The gravy is great - all it needs is a bit of flour, some homemade stock and a splash of milk. I use wondra since it is so easy to whisk in. 

Last time I made this, my BF asked if I would stuff it like a turkey.  I want to try stuffing it next time.  It was a duh moment for me.

This is wonderful and always a hit with everyone that eats it.  Thanks so much for this recipe.

If I could give this recipe a "10" I would!!! It was absolutely fabulous!! I'm giving this a 5 start rating for the cooking method, the chicken was delish and very moist.  I will make again, for sure.....but this spice blend is very salty.  I had read some reviews that warned that....but wanted to see for myself.  Next time I will half the salt.  I made my chicken with bone-in thighs and they were great.

*******update******
used only 2 tsp salt this time around and now the seasoning is perfect for me.  I baked leg quarters at 275 for just short of four hours.  This recipe is very forgiving, simple and a new family favorite!!

text:
Wow! Fantastic! Divine!  What other adjectives can I use to describe this delectible, finger-lickin' good chicken?  I prepared it last night and let it sit all night in the fridge with the "rub" on.  I baked it for about 5 1/2 hours and it was just beautiful!  My husband was raving with every bite!  He likes his whole chicken really well baked; he doesn't like it to be "wet" (juicy) inside.  This was just right; it was very well baked, but was by no means dried out.  It was really perfect.  I can see serving this for guests.  It was such a simple recipe-just requires a little preparation; it's not something you can just think about and bake.  But, how does the saying go?  "Best things come to those who wait"!!  Thanks a million for this one!

text:
Very nice chicken recipe - it really does taste like rotisserie chicken. I used black pepper in place of the white and the skin came out a bit too spicy, so do try to use the white pepper. The one drawback is that compared to my baked chicken, the skin was crispy in some places but a bit tough in others. The chicken itself was well cooked and flavorful. I followed another reviewer's advice and made gravy from the pan drippings, which was excellent. I used an 8x8 baking dish to cook the chicken and this kept more of the liquids in the pan for gravy.

text:
Let me start off by saying a college student so i always look for recipes that are cheap and easy. This was both! I followed the directions but i didnt have Thyme so i just used a few shakes of dried parsley. I used 1 tsp of garlic powder insead of 1/4.I just subbed more black pepper for white pepper cause i didnt have it.  I marinated overnight (18 hours about). I just wrapped the pan in Tin foil. Than i baked at 250 for only e hours (just 1 chicken) it came out so good. At the 2 and a half hour mark and i threw in 3 potatoes.

Everything turned out great, my buddy stopped by and he wouldnt stop telling me how good it was, he wasnts the recipe to make for his family. My only regret is i didnt make 2 chickens. Because me and my friend nearly ate teh whole thing, i had to salvage a plate for my girlfriend, she liked too. Next time i might cut the salt a little and get Thyme. but this is great! I'm gonna make this for my mom next time i see her. An instant classic thanks so much! No more Ramen for me!

text:
Oh, yum! Don't be deterred by the amount of salt, spread out over two chickens it's really not that much. I made a few substitutions. I used: 3tsp kosher flake salt + 1tsp seasoning salt, and substituted lemon pepper for the cayenne. For the last 10 minutes I broiled the chickens for 5 minutes on one side and then flipped them to broil the other side for another 5 minutes so that the skin would crisp up. Those things I think really made a big difference. The flavor was amazing.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe except for using 5 lb. birds. Quite salty...I would halve the amount of salt. In 5 hours even my larger birds reached 180F, but at this temperature the breasts were dry and mealy and the skin was tough. Next time I will cook only to the USDA/FSIS recommended 165F.(http://www.fsis.usda.gov/Fact_Sheets/Chicken_Food_Safety_Focus/index.asp) That said, this is a nice savory dry rub, not hot at all as I had expected. I would give it another try for a shorter time. Update 1/19/16: I've used the rub with half the salt, no garlic (extra onion powder) many times now. I use 2-3 teaspoons per 3# bird and roast  at 350 F. for 75 min, or to 165 F.  I also use it in the crock pot with chicken parts, on low for 5-6 hours. I give it 5 stars with the change in salt and roasting method.

text:
This is a great recipe!! I did change some things. I cooked this in a crockpot and I used 1 5lb roaster. I only added 1 onion in the cavity along with 1 bulb of garlic (peeled & smashed). I used the spices as stated and put it in the fridge overnight. Before I went to work I put 3 balls of foil at the bottom of the crockpot and set the chicken on top. Do Not add any liquid or you will end up with soup. I cooked it on low for 8 hrs. I came home from work to the Wonderful smell of roast chicken. All I had to do was toss a salad and dinner was done 10 minutes after I got home. I will definately make this again.

userID:
2799186
Display Name:
MarkS
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
14
favoritesCount:
35
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty, but it was not fall-off-the-bone moist like I expected. I think it may be in part due to a possibly mis-calibrated oven. I used a single 4.5 lb chicken. I brined the bird for about 3 hours before applying seasoning. The extra salt may have contributed to the dryness.  I used a 1/2 recipe for the rub, using 1 1/2 tsp natural sea salt, omitted white pepper (I don't have any), doubled the black pepper, substituted a pinch of red pepper for the cayenne pepper, and added 1/2 tsp dried rosemary. There was still some seasoning remaining after covering the bird inside and out, so I mixed it with the quartered onion and some lemon juice before stuffing it all into the cavity. I double-wrapped it in plastic and let it sit in the fridge overnight (about 12 hours). I like crispy skin, so I let it sit in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes after removing the plastic wrap so it could dry out a little. Then I roasted it at 250 degrees, with a thermometer in the breast. It was done in 3 1/2 hours.  The white meat was a little drier than I expected, but it all tasted very good. I served it with roasted seasoned potatoes and steamed broccoli. Very good dinner. This is our second favorite chicken recipe, and I'll probably try it again to see if I can improve the dryness.

text:
I followed this recipe exactly and it was absolutely AMAZING!  It tasted a million times better than any rotisserie I've ever bought at the store.  It was so tender that the chicken literally fell apart as soon as I started carving it.  I normally don't eat the skin when I eat chicken, but I couldn't stay away because it was so good.  As suggested by the top reviewer, I made a gravy by adding a can of chicken broth (thickened w/ 2 T corn starch) to the drippings.  It was quite good, but next time, I'll pour off the grease first and just use the brown bits after deglazing (put roasting pan on stove over medium-high heat, pour in enough broth to cover - bring to simmer and scrape off all the brown bits).  I prepared both chickens but immediately put one in the freezer (before cooking and onion) for a future dinner.  I can't wait to have it again!

I forgot to add (like other users) cook the bird UPSIDE down (breast side down) for most of the time. I turn mine up the last 20 minutes or so, but I bake it at a higher temp. country:
None
text:
Thought I'd give this a whirl as it seemed like a breeze to throw in right after lunch for an early dinner... I actually didn't have time (I'm kinda a fly-by-the-seat-of-my-pants kind of girl) to allow the rub to marinate overnight so I was worried that the chicken might be dry, but... IT WAS FABULOUS and *really* juicy! It was worth the time and I know I'll use the method to roast other chickens! I also used the drippings in the bottom of the pan to make a quick gravy to go with the mashed potatoes I put on the side... YUM! ONE NOTE... we have 3 little ones and I knew that the spice would be too much for them so I just used 1/2 the spice mixture on one chicken and put a more tame rub on the other chicken for them. Everyone was happy with the results!

This is a great recipe!! Tried it the first time it was good. The second time took advice from others and put some seasoning under the skin and tied the legs together. I did change some ingredients and I think it turned out even better. I did not have cayenne pepper so I used Old Bay seasoning, doubled the garlic and omitted 1 tsp. of salt and added 1 tsp. of Lawry's seasoning salt. I used all the seasoning on a 5# chicken and let it sit overnight. This recipe is a keeper..  Thanks for sharing!

country:
None
text:
I had an almost 8 lb. Oven Stuffer roaster and was looking for a better way to cook it.  It seemed like the recipe used an excessive amount of salt, so I reduced it by one half.  I roasted the chicken on a rack.  Since I was cooking a large bird, I found I had to turn the oven up to 300ºF for the last hour of roasting in order to reach the internal temperature.  Other than those two changes I followed the recipe exactly.  The chicken was moist, tender, and very flavorful with brown and crispy skin.  This was the best-looking and best-tasting roast chicken I've ever made.  I made gravy from the pan drippings after straining off the grease. It was delicious.  I'll definitely use this recipe again (with the reduced salt amount).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave this recipe 5 stars because it taught me a different technique and it had me successfully using a spice I haven't had much use for until today (paprika). I used an almost 9 pound capon, which actually required an extra 30 minutes, for a total of 5-1/2 hours.  I didn't have white pepper and am not fond of cayenne, so I used only finely ground black pepper and increased the amount to compensate for the others missing.  I thought I'd see if a little brown sugar in the rub would make it sticky (it didn't, but it did balance out the pepper).  I took others' advice and reduced the salt to 1 tablespoon, using coarse kosher salt. I was so nervous with such a long cooking time that I kept checking every hour, but it was done perfectly. I had cool broth from boiling the giblets and I mixed in some cornstarch and deglazed the pan with it, creating a tasty gravy, as others suggested.  I will definitely make this recipe again.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

userID:
1469285
Display Name:
Weezie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4526939.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just call this Roast Sticky Chicken because it does not taste at all like store-bought rotisserie chicken .. but it is fabulous!  No need to marinate overnight, though, because it cooks so slowly, there's plenty of time for the spices to soak in (and I've tried it both ways.)  And don't throw the giblets away, after washing them, roll them in the spices and put them back inside the cavity with the onion.  I made this for my Mom once, and she kept looking in the oven and telling me my chicken was going to be dry - but even she had to admit in the end that it was not at all dry, and now she makes this regularly.  The last time I made this, I cooked it in the crockpot for about 5 hours on High, adding a chicken bouillon cube in 1/2 cup water in the bottom to make sure it had enough moisture, and I chopped up some mushrooms to add to that broth - excellent!  Next time I'm going to do this again, but I'm also going to remove the skin, because I think it will be plenty tasty and much healthier without it.

text:
Giving this recipe three stars because I appreciate the underlying cooking technique of very low heat for very long periods of time more than the recipe itself. I followed the recipe to the letter once I got a fairly unispiring result that was a bit dry and in need of gravy. When I tried the variation of amping up the levels of spices and--crucial for me in terms of tenderness--brining the bird beforehand, then marinating it, then rubbing olive oil and over the skin before roasting as directed, I got a truly standout bird. In either instance, I think the result was acceptable for a beginners' attempt and I do recommend this as a good place to start for those who don't have whole-bird roasting experience.

text:
Moist, tasty, but my bird was only 4lbs and after all the carving and bones, there wasn't much white meat or crispy skin left to eat.  I think I may try this on chicken breasts and bake those instead.  House did smell good, though!  Update: used 6.5lb perdue roaster, did marinade for 24 hours, took 3.5 hrs, half with breast down, half breast up.  In the last hour, I basted with a little butter to crisp it up... DELICIOUS!  Made a fabulous gravy and tasted yummy over mashed potatoes.  Beware drumstick lovers - the chicken is so moist, you can't even salvage the drumstick.. the meat fell right off the bone.. soooooo good.  Update 2: I tried coating boneless skinless breats with this and then sautee-ing it...  eh - a little too spicy for me.. maybe i'll roast the breasts instead - but I do think the skin-on is important because of the flavor.  Stick with the roaster.

text:
Made this last night and it is going to become a regular for us!  It had a great flavor & was SOO tender. My husband & 5 year old picky son ate it up (I peeled off the outer, spicy layer before giving it to my son). Thanks for the great recipe!

Update:  13 years later and this recipe is still my main recipe for whole chickens!  I mix up a big batch of the seasoning to use several meals.  I put some pats (2T) of butter under the skin on the breast and melt some butter to brush on the outside.  Put onion and garlic in the cavity then sprinkle spice generously all over the bird.  A 7lb bird takes about 5-6 hours cooking at 250 (275 degrees for the last 45 minutes).

text:
This is the best roasted chicken I have ever eaten or made. I have tried about five different roasted chicken recipes and this one comes out on the top for sure. The slow cooking allows for a juicy and moist chicken while having a nice crispy outside. The spice rub works really well too and makes for great gravy drippings. Initually I thought the cooking time was a bit long and was really afraid I would end up with a dry roasted chicken, but it was seriously perfect. My three year old had like three helpings and my husband kept nibbeling on it all night. Not a thing I would change about it and this will be our roasted chicken recipe from now on...all the other recipes are going in the trash.

Super good Chicken!  My husband absolutely loved it and he is not a chicken fan.  It made wonderful gravy, in fact my husbands exact words were "some of the best chicken gravy ever."  Which was nice for me, because it was the first time I had ever made gravy.  I only cooked one chicken and was a little short on time so I cooked it for about 2.5 hours at 300.  I basted twice (couldn't help myself).  When you are eating the chicken, the onion flavor is there, but not nearly as prominent as like 45 minutes later when your whole mouth tastes like onion - if you serve for guests, have some MINTS for them!!  Anyways thanks for a great recipe, I will use this time and time again. UPDATE!  Okay so I made this again, and this time I baked it for 5 hours at 250 per the recipe and we didn't like it nearly as much as before - my husband thought the texture was weird.  Also this time I only used part of the onion and used some apple as well, and that was also a mistake, whole onion is needed!  I'm very excited to make it again the way I did the first time!

text:
This recipe is simply amazing! I used half of the dry rub on a 2 lb organic chicken.  Hasn't quite thawed out in the cavity (a habit of freezing everything) but went ahead and marinated the chicken anyway, making sure the onion chunks were covered in the seasoning mix.  Had it marinated overnight and roasting in the oven the next day for 6 hours, basting 3 or 4 times after 3 hours.  Due to my odd dyslexia moments, I preheated and baked it for 250 and not 180 degrees. Luckily the chicken came out moist and not dry at all.  I was skeptic on how it would turn out not using butter or oil but like one of the past reviewer noted, NO additional liquid is needed.  I roasted the chicken in a cake pan and after 6 hours, the chicken sweated out and produced its own yummy juice (makes an awesome gravy btw) that covered half of the cake pan!  The juice kept the bird from drying out. By far the best, if not better than the store's deli. Hate to say it but it beats out Whole Food Market by 1 full star.

Oh my goodness!! This is the best chicken I have ever eaten!!

We don't care as much for dark meat so we made this with bone in breasts. We cut the onion and put the onion pieces under each breast piece and seasoned the meat top and bottom. 

We basted the chicken twice during the cooking time (after about 3 and 4 hours) and roasted it altogether for about 4 1/2 hours after letting it sit in the spices for 5 hours. It was fall-off-the-bone tender and the meat was seasoned through and through.

My husband who has never asked me to make a chicken dish has already asked for this one again soon. High praise indeed!!

userID:
2047349
Display Name:
StephanieV
isPro:

followersCount:
1

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/18.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW!! If I could give this more stars I certainly would! It was delicious and juicy! I did make a few changes...but very slight ones. I cut back on the salt and used 1/2 of what was called for. I added a little more cayenne, and because I was out of thyme I used oregano instead. I rubbed my chicken with garlic infused olive oil before putting the rub on. I also put 3 cloves of garlic in with the onions. I let it marinade overnight. I roasted breast side up on a roasting rack so the bottom would not get soggy. I only baked one 5 pound chicken. I roasted it at 350 for 4 hours and then I tented with foil and let rest about 20 minutes. It was perfect! The skin was crisp and beautiful. The flavors were not too strong...just right. Most importantly it was super moist and juicy! My family said it was the best roast chicken recipe I have made by far and I had no leftovers at all! So easy and super delicious!!! Thank you so much for a wonderful recipe that will be a family favorite from now on!!! Kudos!

text:
I have been making this recipe for a couple of years, and my family LOVES it! I tweak mine a bit; we found it a bit too spicy for the little ones, so all I do is half the amount of the "hot" ingredients: paprika, white pepper, ablack pepper, and cayenne pepper. I also cook mine as soon as I rub the spices on. After the first hour of cooking, I baste the chicken every 30 minutes with its own juices. This chicken turns out so fall off the bone yummy!!!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2006-02-11T07:53:59.747
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1452636
Display Name:
TUNISIANSWIFE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
141
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
431
favoritesCount:
410
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/933710.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is probably one of the best oven roasters I have ever made in regards to taste, moistness, and appearance.  I had a 3.97 lb. Amish roaster chicken and wanted to really do well by it.  I have seen this popular recipe come up in the reviews alot so decided to try.  I am not disappointed.  I halved the spices since only using 1 bird and used 1 1/2 tsp. salt instead of 2 since I also wanted to put some of the spice mixture between the skin and breast.I was leary that all that salt would make the breast meat dry but it was wonderful. Had dehydrated onions and no powder so just used 2 tsp. of them and put them in with my spices and ground with mortel and pestal to a fine powder.  I did add 1/2 tsp. Old Bay and 1/2 tsp. Chicken Barbeque spice I bought by mistake, and 1 tsp. dried thyme.  Put everything in a gallon ziplock overnight in the fridge stuffed with the onion.  Because I had to use my oven for other things, I did bake at 300 degrees w/meat thermometer and after 3.15 hours, it was done.  Added no broth, wine, or water.  Put it on my broiler pan so it was totally 'airborne' and kept brushing the juices on every half hour or so.  I let it rest for 20 minutes before I cut into it and it is incredible. I noticed it does have a sticky texture to the skin as I was cutting it. Wonderful recipe that can be tweaked to suit a particular taste.  I would love to try this "beer can" style sometime; would be great done on the grill spit.

5

This is a great recipe.  I changed the seasonings a bit based on what I had around the house.  I did not have onion powder or white pepper, so I doubled up the garlic powder and black pepper, respectively.  I also used rosemary instead of thyme.  In terms of the cooking, I forgot to put the chicken in the oven five hours in advance.  So, I cooked it at a higher temp for 1.5 hours.  Even after that, it still turned out to be really juicy and soooo yummy.  I can imagine how much better it tastes after slow cooking it.

text:
I cook the chicken(s) a little differently. I use my rotisserie on my grill and it is wonderful and flavorful. I do not use the onion in the cavity. I also rarely remember to marinate ahead of time and it still comes out right. For some that have tried this in the pan and have had poor results, try this trick: use the Reynolds oven bags and put a couple of toothpicks in the top of the chicken so that the bag does not rest on the bird and stick. Off to make a couple for dinner right now.

country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic recipe, and I'm someone who loves chicken, and collects and tries many ways to make it. Flavor, texture, moistness are all excellent. It's important to use a 4 lb chicken; cut the time a little if you use a smaller bird so the meat doesn't dry out. I don't care for cayenne pepper, and leaving it out didn't do any harm.  A variation of this recipe is to add the onions in chopped form right before roasting, not the night before. Either way, don't skip the onions; I believe that cooking them inside the cavity adds to both the flavor and moistness of the meat.

I also drizzled a little maple syrup over the chicken which made it a bit sticky just like a rotisserie chicken. Also added 3 cloves of garlic in the cavity to give it that extra boost. A definate must try, you'll love it!

text:
Better than any supermarket roasted chicken, better than Costco's also.  My family is gah-gah over this recipe.  The aroma is wonderful.  I add 1 cup water at the bottom of the roasting pan and make sure to baste the chicken regularly during the 5 hours.  Before serving, I slice the chicken breast nicely and place them into the juices to absorb the most wonderful flavors, then I transfer all the pieces to serving tray and pour more of the juices over it all.  Rave Reviews guaranteed.  Thank you

text:
This was great; worked perfectly. My picky husband loved it, I loved it, and I even served it to my mother-in-law. She raved about it. I had never baked a whole chicken before and this made it so simple. I rubbed the spices on about 6 hours before cooking, and did one chicken for four hours. I mixed the spices the night before and put them in a baggie. So the prep was very quick the next day. I will definitely make this again.

text:
This chicken was very good.  4 hours cooking time was definitely enough.  We basted it about 4 times.  Beautiful dark brown color with lots of delicious juice.  Heavy grease and fat on the juice, but just skim that off.  Added 2 cloves of garlic and onions in each cavity. rapped it in plastic and let it marinate overnight.  Next time I will add a little more cayenne and garlic powder since we like things very spicey.  The spice blend tastes very much like poultry seasoning with the extras added in. I will definitely make this again.

I used drumsticks instead a whole chicken.  The seasonings really made the chicken much more flavorful.  If using simple cuts of chicken, you'll want to cut the time in the oven since it will not take as long to cook.  The result wasn't really like "restaurant style rotissere chicken", but it was very tasty and a healthier alternative to frying!  Thanks for sharing!

text:
I'm not a fan of baked chicken, so I thought I'd try this and see if I liked it. I did. I actually used the rotissery in my toaster oven, and I got an excellent chicken out of it. Two, really. I roasted two of the smallest chickens, not actually classified as Cornish game hens, that I could find. I didn't plan far enough ahead to refrigerate, just stuck them on the spit with one small whole onion for each chicken and let them twist in the heat. I did cut the cayenne in half. This will join the rotation at my house. Thanks for sharing, Sue!

text:
Hi there, I made this last night and I was impressed by the results. It was flavorful, moist and the skin was crispy. I see some reviews were saying 5 hours is too long but for me it was accurate and I was cooking one chicken. I also was checking the temperature after 2 1/2 hours and then again around 4 hours. So each person's oven varies and you do what is best for your oven. Use the 5 hours as a gage as to how long you should roast it in the oven. And I am glad to see I can rotisserie a chicken when I want to. Thank you.

this is an absolutely amazing recipe! In a pinch once i roasted the bird without letting it sit overnight and it wasnt nearly as good and flavorful.  the drippings from this make the best gravy, I use the fat to make a rue then add the juice topped up to 2 cups and a splash of wine. soooooo good! thanks for this recipe. it's a staple in our fall/winter meals.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used an actual rotisserie for this recipe, modifying it so that I had plenty of leftover to baste the chicken -- just in case. Starting off on high heat for 10 minutes, I turned the grill burners to low, put an aluminum foil "boat" to catch the juices. I let it go 2 hours like this until the internal temp hit between 160 and 180.

The chicken was pull apart tender, though strictly speaking, that was the result of a 4 hour brine; no-brine=dry chicken; brine=incredibly juicy chicken. But I liked this recipe. I'll try it again with a few minor modifications to suit my own tastes.

Have to be honest...I wasn't expecting much..just trying to find a half decent roast chicken recipe. I didn't have time to marinade. It really didn't matter. Shoved the onion and some garlic cloves into the chicken. Used the spice to give it a good COMPLETE rub covering. Slow roast at 250. Wow!!! This was great.  Nice and crispy and flavorful. Definitely a MAKE AGAIN!!

userID:
24883767
Display Name:
Tom
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First, and most important, you do not cook poultry for a set amount of time, you cook until an internal temperature is reached.  With this recipe, 180 degrees fahrenheit.  I have used an inexpensive Acurite model 00993ST for years.  $25.00.  Or, google "Best digital meat thermometers" and pick your own.  Second, your oven temperature.  I would make a bet I think is safe that most ovens are not within 20 degrees of what you set it at.  I used my Thermoworks IR-GUN-S laser infrared thermometer to check my oven.($33.00) A word about oven thermometers.  The mercury bulb type are almost impossible to read. The round bi-metal stripe type are wildly inaccurate.    Put an empty small ceramic dish, like a ramekin, in the oven, and put on 250 degrees.  Aim the laser on it.  Mine settled on 220 .  So I had to set it on 280 in order to get 250.  (As you can probably tell by now, I take my cooking very seriously)  For my 4+ pound chicken, it took 3hrs 45min to come to 180 degrees.  NOT 5 hours.  It turned out great, but would have been like shoe leather after 5 hours.

I have learned over the years to treat recipes as inspirational guidelines, not gospel.  Happy Cooking.
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2018-12-14T03:12:33.463

text:
I've made this many times, it's always great! I've even made it with turkey and it came out great!  I do a couple of additions.  I add onions in the cavity along with the celery.  I carefully separate the skin from the breast using fingers flat against the breast.  I spread 1/4 cup of softened butter or margarine in-between the skin and the meat, carefully making sure the skin doesn't tear.  This makes the white meat on the breast extra tender and tasty.  Everyone loves it every time!

I followed recipe exactly. After I got the onion inside the cavity, I tied the legs with twine. Chicken turned out moist and tender. This was soooooo good ! I halved the recipe as I was only making one chicken - 3.5 pounds - also didn’t have white pepper but didn’t really worry about that . I cooked at 250 for 4 hours, amazing chicken, so tasty ! I made gravy with the drippings , just heated the drippings until bubbling, whisked in some flour and added water from potatoes I cooked and then roasted, I didn’t have any chicken stock and honestly, the flavours were so good it didn’t need stock , water was just fine! DELICIOUS! I will be rubbing my Christmas turkey with this as well !!! And an onion in the cavity - so so good!! And so easy

country:
None
text:
OK, I followed the recipe unlike some other people who said "I followed the recipe except i used parts of chicken and a crock pot". Guess what?? that's not the recipe! Yes, you can (and I did) add a few extra spices or leave out the white pepper (who has it?) but the main thing is a whole chicken scrubbed out, seasoned inside and out and baked at 250 degrees  uncovered for 4 to 5 hours depending on size of chicken and your oven. Mine came out perfect obviously because I gave it max stars. I cooked mine while I was on the golf course. Came home and took temps in the thickest part and it was 165 to 170. I then basted, covered with aluminum foil and put it  back in the still warm but NOT ON oven until dinner. No dry meat (even the breast was moist). Simply delicious. Better than any grocery store but not as good as Pollo Lucas in Mexico. But a lot closer  and more convenient.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4049308.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this recipe almost as written, but since it was too warm out today to fire up the oven, I used the rotisserie on my grill. The chicken was moist and not dry; flavor was as wonderful as it smelled. I only made a few changes since we were using the rotisserie: (1) mixed the seasoning with about 1/4 cup melted butter to baste the chicken. Then, we continued basting occasionally with the pan drippings; (2) did not refrigerate for the 4-6 hours and I don't think it is a necessary step even if I made it in the oven, but I'll have to try that another day. To do this on the rotisserie: tie the legs and wings and just follow the manufacturer instructions for temperature and method. You'll need indirect heat and put a pan underneath to catch the drippings. Removed chicken from rotisserie when temp reached 165 F and tented with foil to let rest. The flavor of the seasoning mix for the chicken was excellent for us. Next time I'd like to put a little seasoning between skin and breasts to get a little more flavor on the meat as we usually do. Overall, very good and will make this again. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I made one 6 lb chicken, it took about 4hrs @ 250. Meat was so tender and skin was perfectly crisp, not at all chewy. I didn’t follow the recipe to a T, and by not marinating my chicken like it instructs, I lost a ton of flavor. I did however add carrot, celery and garlic so that somewhat made up for my lack of spices... I think next time I will double up on the spices, you lose a lot from the plastic wrap. Overall, this will be my go-to method from now on.

I followed the recipe exactly and it didn’t end up sticky as the name says, just a bunch of dried spices and herbs on equally dry skin. The chicken did come out tender but if I wasn’t on Mat leave and had the time to throw this in the oven and wait, I personally don’t think this is worth 5 hours of baking. I may attempt again and read reviewers changes to see if that works, but it really wasn’t that big of a deal this first go.

text:
Followed the recipe as closely as possible. I even had white pepper which added a delicious fragrance to the chicken! I didn't have a full tsp of dried thyme but I used as much as I had. I didn't have time to marinate overnight, but I was able to marinate the chicken with the spices (wrapped in cling wrap) for about 3-3.5 hours.  I roasted at 275 for the first 45 minutes, then lowered to 250 degrees for about 3 more hours. It was perfect! Delicious, flavorful, juicy, perfect chicken! Hubby loved it as well. Will definitely make again!

text:
I am giving this a 5 rating as the flavor was delicious!  I do however, think my chicken selection was terrible which led to a rubbery bird with inedible skin.  After googling rubbery chicken, it appears my bird selection was the culprit.  I purchased a 7 lb bird with an unknown brand name.  Other than the texture, I would definitely make this again.  I would choose fresh chickens if possible and with the lowest injection rate possible.  I used this chicken to make chicken enchilada's, chicken salad and as an addition to my dogs food.  Everyone was happy!

text:
the combination of the spice mixture and slow-roasting make this a great recipe.  while i can tell that the original recipe is out-of-the-park good, i made a few slight modifications for one reason or another: my mom had a tooth pulled recently so i subbed ancho chili powder for the cayenne and i also subbed in smoked paprika. i also pulled up the skin a little and put the rub underneath as well as on top. finally, i rubbed a little bit of olive oil on the bird just before popping it in the oven. golden brown and delicious!

This is truly the best chicken I have ever made. I followed the directions exactly. I knew there was no way I was going to be able to leave that chicken alone in the oven for 5 hours so I actually left the house while it was cooking. I thought for sure I would come home to a dry husk of chicken. Instead it was wonderful! All of my extremely picky children ate this and there are very few meals I can say that about. I even made this for Thanksgiving instead of a turkey. It was the most relaxing Thanksgiving I've had. I just made it the night before and heated up my side dishes right before I took the chickens out of the oven.

text:
Sue Rogers, you're a chicken genius! haha.  This will be one of a couple of new recipes in the arsenal.  I did one chicken instead of 2 and lessened the spices (preference) and I'm so glad I tried this recipe. The BEST part??? LESS MESS in the oven!  Hardly any spatters and I have a Stainless Steel oven (electric) that  I can't use steel wool on - it's only oven cleaner and a rag...and elbow grease.  So I am beyond THRILLED to have this "new" method at my disposal.  I bought a 6.5 pound chicken and mine took just under 5 hours with an electric (not convection) oven. I have tried this "dry brine" trick before on pork shoulder. Salt all over, wrap and refrigerate overnight and the meat explodes with juiciness. The magic is more of the salt's doing but the rest of the spices are terrific, including the white pepper. Thanks so much!  **Have made this 2 more times with one being parts only, not the whole bird. GREAT!**

text:
I made this as written and it marinated for two days. I was worried about it being too strong or spicy for my in laws, both in their 80's. but it was fine. I really enjoyed the flavor and so did they. It was a hit. I normally brine my chicken but this was good without being in a 24 hr brine. The only thing I did different is I buttered under the breast skin and I sprayed oil on the chicken about three different times during cooking. It was looking a little dried out. I think it helped. The skin was fine.  I keep oil in a spray bottle for my air fryer. I will make this again and again. Very very good.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this just like the recipe but with a 6.5 lb roaster. Preped it Saturday night and in the oven at 930 on Sunday. The internal temp stalled at about 165 at 5 hours then in the last hour went right to 180 at 6 hours. I did go to convection on the last hour, that really helped to crisp up the skin.  Once I let it rest I removed the breasts, leg/thighs and wings. The wish bone pulled right out and I was also able to remove the back meat with no effort. I've been cooking for years and this is the best oven roasted chicken I have ever made. It was juicy, flavorful and the skin was to die for haha ?? sorry Dr Darzev, had to eat it. Can't say enough about it. If you don't like a little bite, leave out to cayenne. Great recipe!  I'm going to try this on the smoker to see how that goes.

text:
I made this recipe as written with the exception of two 5 lb chickens vs 3 to 4 lb. The seasoning was excellent.  Very good flavor.  The aroma of the chicken slowly roasting in the oven was awesome. It was through out the house. I started checking the internal temperature at 4 hours. The final check on the internal temperature was at 5 hours at 175 degrees . We let it rest for 10 minutes before carving. We used one chicken that night and the next night we used the other chicken for creamy chicken and wild rice soup found on allrecipes site which is 5 stars.
Thanks 
Randy

text:
I had the oven at 450 just to brown the chicken for 10 minutes.  Then I lowered it to 250 and I followed the recipe exact.  I used a 5 lb chicken.  I checked it after 3 hours because I wanted to add some small red and white potatoes to roast alongside.  The chicken was done.  I took it out of the oven to let it rest and roasted some potatoes on a separate pan.  i made a gravy with the drippings, cornstarch and broth.  It was delicious.  I wasn't ready to eat because I thought it would take 5 hours or even 4, so I cut off a thigh and leg and reheated it for a few minutes when the potatoes were almost done.  I'll try it again maybe putting the potatoes in at the beginning.

text:
I made this today for Sunday dinner and it was delicious.  I  cut up potatoes and carrots and added them the last hour.  However, when I removed the chicken after the last hour the vegetables were not done. So I cooked the vegetables for an extra half hour and turned up the temp to 375 degrees and then they were done. I also mixed some corn starch and water and made an awesome gravy right in the pot with the potatoes. I will definitely use this recipe in the future. Thanks Sue for sharing this.

text:
Spices were spot on.  Nice and tasty.  My 5# bird took 4-1/2 hours to bake perfectly.  I did begin at 500 degrees and dropped it immediately to 250F.  Created a nice brown "crust" on the chicken.   Although the instructions didn't indicate, I did baste 4 times, also pouring some white wine over it halfway.  I did add some celery, carrots and garlic to the onions for aromatic influence.  Will definitely make this again.  Never roasted a bird at this low temperature, but it works!  Moist and not dried out as I thought it would.  5 stars!

text:
I am a bigger fan of Blasted Chicken which can be done just one hour before eating with little prep.  Just sprinkle all the spices you like all over the bird (a young bird about 3 1/2 to 4 lbs.) and roast at 450 degrees for one hour.  The chicken that results has crispy brown skin and melt in your mouth, juicy, tender meat. I make it often on demand!

text:
This is the technique that I'm going to use from now on whenever I make a roasted chicken.  

The meat was moist and very tender, the seasoning flavor penetrated the meat nicely and the skin was crispy and well-adhered to the meat.

The seasoning I used was completely different - olive oil, a little rice vinegar, salt, poultry seasoning, celery inside the chicken - and I didn't let the seasoning settle in before putting it in the oven.

text:
I make this every Sunday and my family loves it! I use half the spices for just one chicken each week and save the rest for the following week. Before the spice rub I rub it with a little olive oil. The key to making the chicken skin crisp yet sticky is to periodically coat it in it's juices while it's baking. The meat always falls right off the bone. I wouldn't change a thing!

None
text:
Awesome chicken!! 
When following someone's recipe you have to use common sense. If there is something in the recipe that you don't like, then don't use it. You also need to know if your oven bakes hotter or cooler. I take into consideration what other reviewers have done differently and adjust to what sounds like it would either make it seem better to my taste! Following a recipe exactly isn't always going to yield the same results. I use a recipe as a guideline and add or delete things that I personally know will give me the best result. I have incorporated a few changes made to this recipe by other reviewers and I do love the low and slow aspect of making this roast chicken. When Sue named this chicken "sticky" I don't think she meant it literally. Again...recipes are a guideline for me and I always incorporate into a recipe my own ideas of what are tried and true outcomes to a delicious dish.

Made this with a few changes (hot paprika for cayenne) and smoked salt.  This was the best chicken we have ever eaten.  since we always use organic chickens they cook in a shorter time.  I cooked it two hours breast down and two hours breast up.  Basted when I turned it over and again about half an hour before I took it out of the oven.  The bones came right out and straight into the stock pot.  ! quart of stock from one chicken carcass and we froze the second chicken with the seasoning and I know it will be just as good as the first one.  Great recipe

text:
DELICIOUS EASY This works well in the slow cooker.
Get fresh chicken, rub, and freeze. When needed  thaw overnight,
Let marinade a bit, pop in slow cooker 4 hours low.
Skin isn't crispy, but usually removing anyway. Clean 
meat off bones,  great dinner, or great lunch meat
for week. Check chicken, Slow Cookers are different.
Can go faster than you think.

text:
This was very moist.  I found the seasonings needed to be pumped up and I cooked it for 4 hours instead of 5 as my chickens were smaller.  Do NOT do what one person suggested - putting the potatoes and carrots in the pan with the chicken on top.  Even after 4 hours the potatoes were still not cooked!  It takes a very long time and I don't think that it is really any better than a chicken cooked for 1 1/2-2 hours at 350 seasoned nicely and a brushing of soy sauce on top.

text:
made this last night exactly how the recipe says to... 
First off, the chicken isn't "Sticky" so not sure about that description. In my opinion, not enough salt and while it was moist inside it lacked flavor. Though the onion stuffed inside permeates the meat, so you do get some onion flavor.
I typically make my chicken off a Thomas Keller recipe. Simply salt and pepper the chicken, then add thyme & bake. I would say the "sticky chicken" recipe is fine but not outstanding

I followed this recipe exactly and it came out perfect! I let two 2lb chickens marinade overnight in a ziplock bag. Cooked for 5 hrs on 250 degrees in a roasting rack. This is one of tenderest chickens I have ever fixed.  The flavor was amazing. The only ingredient I didn't add was the cayenne. I didn't want them too spicy. With the left overs I shredded the remaining meat and made enchiladas. This will go into my regular bi-weekly rotation.

text:
Ok, made this today because it sounded really good. The smell as it cooked was delicious. Unfortunately, the taste didn't match the scent. I followed this exactly as written save for using it with one chicken and only 4 hours cook time as recommended by others.  No changes to the ingredients, the prep or the manner of cooking. The chicken was fantastically moist, even the white meat which I normally can't stand was good for moistness. The flavor, however, was so overwhelmingly onion flavored parts of the chicken were inedible. I am also not sure why this is called sticky chicken. the skin was crisp, but it was dry with no stickiness at all and was nothing like any rotisserie chicken I've ever had. I love the concept and will use the cooking method again but unless someone can suggest anything I may have done wrong I won't be using this recipie again.

text:
This is good, not great.  I halved the recipe to 2 one bird for two people.  Lift the skin over the breasts and work about half the seasoning mix under the skin, then massage it all around.   This gets the flavor deep into the chicken.  Put the other half of the seasoning inside the bird and on the outside of the skin. 

The wife and I really like Sam's Club rotisserie chickens.  This recipe will not replace those, but it is a good seasoning mix, a little different than our normal Thanksgiving styled recipe that uses parsley, sage, rosemary, and thyme.

Display Name:
Jennifer Keller

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2058394.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made it and I wanted to say that the issue of the time is a little funny.  5 hours would have been too long.  I calculated that for my 4.5 pound organic free range chicken it would take 4 hours but it only took 3.5 hours.  The seasoning was perfect.  I did use the white pepper because I had it on hand and would recommend people get some and keep it.  The different peppers taste different, white, black and red all have a different kind of heat.  The chicken was juicy and the gravy was awesome.  I did take the advice of some reviewers and put some butter on the bird as it came closer to being done and basted it a bit.  I also did season it and put it in a bag overnight with an onion and some garlic in the cavity along with some seasoning.  I eat a lot of chicken and prefer to grill it often, so I will use this seasoning the next time I grill a bird (I often butterfly them).  This was not the best chicken I have ever had but it is a really good one.  You do need to be aware if you are making 1 bird 5 hours may be to long if it is under 6 lbs.

Display Name:
MissSilver

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First off, lets give credit where credit is due, this is originally called Mimi's sticky chicken recipe and came across the recipe back in the early 2000's. The author of this recipe should have mentioned this when sharing it on all recipes.

I've made this chicken several times and it is always a hit... well, not for those who complained that cayenne does not belong on a chicken. Baste no more than 2 times or the skin tends to blacken even given the low cooking temp. 

I always double my spices and herbs when making this chicken and always keep a batch of the mix in my spice rack which also works well on big chicken legs.  Most important part, try to have your spices on the chicken a minimum of 12 hours in advance of cooking the bird, makes a world of difference in the stickiness  of the chicken. 

I also mist it gently with water after sprinkling the spices before I send it back in the fridge for 12h to 24h before cooking.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I make this nearly every single week!

I also use this recipe to cook the chicken in my convection oven. I cook at 400 degrees for about 1.5 hours for a 6 lb. chicken. It comes out nearly as good as the slow roasting in the oven. 

I changed the recipe slightly for the tastes of my family - reduce black pepper to 1/4 teaspoon and omit the cayenne completely.

Prepare for lots of compliments!

text:
The chicken was moist and the dry rub tasted very good. I thought the words "Rotisserie Style" in the title was a bit misleading, however, because while the dry rub colored the skin to look like rotisserie chicken, it tasted more like medium-hot wings. Further, I baked the chicken to an internal temperature of 165F (rather than to 180F which might overcook the meat) since "whole poultry" is fully cooked at 165F.

You had me at 'sticky'.  I love rotisserie chicken and couldn't wait to try this recipe.  I followed the recipe exactly except I used one larger chicken instead of two smaller ones.  I did everything like the recipe said to, including seasoning the chicken, putting it in a zip loc bag and refrigerating it over night.  The meat was delicious and juicy but the skin...the part I was really excited about...was anything but sticky.  It was dry and tough.  When I checked it about halfway through the cooking time and saw that it looked so dry, I rechecked the recipe thinking I must have done something wrong.   Nope, I did everything according to the directions.   So I don't know why the skin came out like that.  If anyone has any ideas for me, please let me know.  I really wanted to love this chicken.

I used one 7 lb whole chicken. I cut all of the spices in half. I also added 4 cloves of garlic to the quartered onion on the inside. I did let it sit overnight for almost 24 hrs wrapped in seran wrap. For the cooking time I placed the chicken in the oven @250 for 2 1/2 hours. The temperature was then turned up to 350 for 1 hour. Once the chicken was removed the pan juices were drizzled on top. I let it sit for about 20 minutes. Came out delicious! Tasted just like it came from a rotisserie.
