text:
The chicken tasted great.  We made gravy from the juices, too.  I only tweaked the recipe slightly.  I used 1 larger chicken. Based on other reviews, I doubled the garlic powder.  I didn't have white pepper so I replaced it with coarse black pepper.  Before I rubbed the chicken with the mixture, I used a fork to poke holes in the skin.  I also rubbed some of the mixture under the skin.  Although I didn't cover it with plastic wrap, I did let it sit in the refrigerator to marinate for about 3.5 hours.  I just had it covered with aluminum foil which stayed on during the cooking process.

text:
Love this recipe!! I've made this many times, the only things I do different is using one whole fryer (about 7 pounds) and using my slow cooker instead. It's so easy to prepare the night before (I don't use the white pepper though, just increase the black pepper and cayenne), wrap it up, place on a plate in the fridge, and in the morning put in my crockpot for about 8 hours on low. I always put 4-5 aluminum foil balls underneath the chicken. I place a few pats of salted butter on the top and again before I serve. It's always a hit!! Thank you for the recipe!!

userID:
9763835
Display Name:
Pineygirl12

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always make a recipe exactly as written the first time, and this was no different except my butcher gave me two 4-pound fryers (less meat). I'll insist on roasters next time.
This was fantastic! I marinated it in the rub for five hours and cooked it for another five. The skin was super crispy and the flavors penetrated everywhere. Even with all that pepper it was only mildly spicy - just enough to lend interest.
I highly suggest going to the effort of getting the white pepper. Having cooked with it before I know that it makes a major difference.
Around the 4th hour I melted some butter on top of the chickens, then basted them with the liquid after taking them out to rest.
The kids said it was the best homemade chicken they've had - as good if not better than the rotisserie chickens we've purchased.
A definite keeper - and so easy to make that you can run errands, clean house - whatever - while the chickens are cooking!

text:
This is the best chicken ever !!!  Slow roasting makes it extremely juicy and tender. The spices work great together- for our family I lessened the Cajun pepper by half (a little spicy for our taste) and I added 2 Tbs of Brown Sugar and a little cinnamon OMG good. When I boil it down to make soup I don't even have to add any additional spices just add chicken broth. Makes incredible chicken salad too, I add celery and red grapes - wow definitely a family favorite.

text:
Wanted to find a chicken rotisserie recipe and this is it!Easy with ingredients that I had in my pantry. Husband loved it and requested it every week! The changes I made were; Changed serving size to 4, did a pinch of salt versus the 2 teaspoons. After making the recipe I felt it had plenty of salt taste. Also since I put the chicken in a plastic bag in the frig to marinate some of the seasoning comes off when I do it. Before cooking I make the seasoning again and put it on the chicken before cooking. The  taste is wonderful! Perfect!

Seasonings didn't really get to the meat thru the skin.  5 hours was too long, checked it at 4:15 hrs. and was at 195.  Breast was overcooked and dry.  I could see it having the texture of a rotisserie chicken if cooked to an internal temp. of 165-170  Next time if I try it again, I'll put seasoning under skin and on skin and check temp starting at 2.5 hrs, might be a great recipe then.

country:
None
text:
Ive noticed quite a few readers say they skipped adding the white pepper when making this stating they used black pepper instead.  White pepper adds a unique flavour and is different from black pepper. You can add it to many and any recipe. Its actually is one of the 'secret' ingredients in Kentucky Fried Chicken recipe.

text:
I can't rave enough about this recipe. I've made it numerous times. I don't always follow the recipe for the baking time but when I do it's worth the extra bit of effort. I have made up a huge batch of the spice mix and often will just spice up a chicken, fill the cavity with chopped onions and bake it as usual. I have cut back on the cayenne as we find it a bit too hot for us. When I have fresh rosemary I will add it in the cavity and stuff some under the skin. I have added dried rosemary to the spice mix too.  I always get rave reviews when I serve this to company.

text:
I have made this for years, found the recipe in the newspaper. I do one chicken, breast side down and dec. the time to 4 hours. 250 deg. is perfectly safe, it is not a typo. I do baste the chicken every 15 min. for the last hour. Place on rack when removing from oven and let it rest with foil over it..

text:
I have to say I am not much of a chicken person.  But I have been sick and stuck in the house and thought I would give this a try since I have time on my hands!  This was by far the BEST chicken I have had.  They one thing that people don't tell you is that the chicken actually takes on the taste of the spices you put all over it the night before!   I have had regular old white chicken blahhhhh this was so much more!  And some people skip the white pepper...total must because it's more robust than the regular black pepper.  The longer you keep it in the fridge the better it will be!  I followed this to the T and was so happy with it!  Don't cut corners or skip or add anything...you won't be sorry!  I shared this with my mom and aunt and they can't wait to make it.  Thanks for an awesome recipe!!!!

text:
My 2 cents is that 180 degrees is technically overdone.   If you trust Google - it says 165 is safe and moist; so now you decide when to take it out.  (That might explain why a few people said it turned out dry.)   I do love people's suggestions so I added potatoes and carrots to the pan as well as made my best-ever gravy from the juices with chicken stock, cream, flour and bay leaf.  Someone suggested adding garlic cloves, but uh, that detracted for me because garlic takes on an earthy flavor when baked this long and that didn't complement this dish.   Speaking of baking so long, yes it's the secret to tender juicy chicken, but we live in FL so more heat in the house is the last thing we need.  I'm going to try it again but on the grill, maybe spatchcock it or use the cast iron pan, but still slow and low heat.   Or, buy it at Costco which is actually cheaper...lol but this was fun and I loved the recipe, thank you!!!  P.S.  It actually was very good without adding butter or oil - go figure!

text:
I completed my grocery shopping today just so I could get a fresh chicken to make this recipe.  I used the spices written except needed to cut back on the paprika due to dietary needs (my husband).  While reading the recipe I saw that it should be refrigerated; unfortunately I did not.  I was concerned as it cooked that it would not turn out very good.  Well I must say this chicken is awesome.  I wonder what it would be like if I did refrigerate it.  As one reviewer negatively put it, she could just  drive down the street and get a roasted chicken as it would save her time and money.  Yes that is true.  I could have picked one up from Costco.  But I must say, I did not think anybody could beat the Costco roasted chicken.  Well I have now found a recipe that can.  I also made gravy out of the drippings, and it was the best gravy I have ever, ever made.  I had a small chicken, so I kept an eye on the meat thermometer.  It was done in about 3.5 hours.  Thank you for submitting such a great recipe.  Next time I will make 2, and the second one I will make White Chicken Enchiladas.

text:
I used this recipe for a chicken I smoked alongside some ribs and it turned out fantastic. I added the rub to some melted butter and minced garlic then rubbed it under the skin of the chicken. It was on the smoker for approximately 4 hours and I occasionally sprayed it with a 50/50 mix of apple juice and water. The skin was golden brown and crispy, the chicken juicy and the flavor was delicious. It still tasted like chicken but had a little smoke and zing to it. I've used this a few times and once I even injected the mixture into the bird. This will be a frequent flyer on my summer BBQ list. 

Oh, I don't bother with putting anything in the cavity. I don't notice any difference one way or the other...

text:
This works so well in the crock pot! We usually do one chicken at a time on high for 1hr per pound. The meat just falls off the bone! I cut up a small onion to put on the bottom of the crock pot to prevent any sticking, just in case. We've been cooking at least 2 chickens every Sunday so we can eat it through the week for lunches and quick dinners. Just pull the chicken off the bone, bag it up into servings, and freeze!

userID:
5875122
Display Name:
Beverly

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe.  I was skeptical at first thinking the skin wouldn't be crispy but it is.  I made this as written except for the white pepper.  I didn't have any.  I only made one chicken so I have enough of the seasonings (saved in a mason jar) for the next time I make this chicken.  The seasonings are great!  When I roast a whole chicken, I cut out the backbone with kitchen shears and lay the chicken flat breast side up.  It is so much easier to carve.  I would suggest using a meat thermometer.  My single chicken that was 6lbs took about 4 hours.  The one thing I would like to suggest is DON'T FORGET TO BASTE THE CHICKEN WITH THE DRIPPINGS WHILE COOKING.  I didn't, and the skin was a little dry but the chicken was very good.  I will definitely be making this again.   When the chickens are on sale, I can get 3 meals for 2 out of one chicken.  Can't beat that.

Very good flavor. I made it using 9 whole chicken wings instead of a whole chicken. I cut the recipe in half since I was not cooking that much chicken. I placed the wings in a plastic storage bag and made sure all chicken was covered with the spices, diced an onion, and placed it in the bag with the chicken, then stored in the refrigerator overnight. I baked in a roasting pan uncovered in the oven at 375 degrees for an hour. Very good recipe. This is now my go-to recipe for baked chicken. Thanks for the recipe.

userID:
8111266
Display Name:
Anne Hubbard
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2757538.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used all the ingredients listed in this recipe. The only change was that I used a 6 1/2 lb. chicken instead of two small chickens, and baked at 250 for 4 hours. It's excellent for dinner, salads, or sandwiches. I don't think it's possible to get rotisserie chicken in an electric oven no matter how you do it. I've tried several methods and they just don't measure up. I would have given this a five star, but because it was touted as "rotisserie, sticky" I gave it four stars. But, I will certainly make this again.

After reading so many reviews on the negative side, I would start checking the temp. after 2-2 1/2 hours for a reading of 165. If it reaches that temp, then it's done. For sticky chicken it must have brown sugar in the seasoning.  However, if you use sugar, it's best to use small chickens and cook at a high heat for a much shorter amount of time.  Hope this helps...

16486523
Display Name:
Asad Al-Kharafi
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2620775.jpg
city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love all the ingredients listed here, but this will not give you a rotisserie chicken "taste" I will tell you how to achieve the real taste.

Follow all directions above (as far as the ingredients go) 

Before placing your chicken into the oven, you need to "flash fry" both sides of the chicken without over cooking it ( aim for light golden) After you "flash fry" in your oil of choice, place the chicken into the oven covered with aluminum foil and cook for the normal amount of time (35-45 mins) on 375-425.  After the chicken Is throughly cooked . Remove foil and place your oven on "broil". Allow both sides to broil(turn your chicken over just once)  until the Chicken is golden brown. Allow to cool and serve ... This will taste just like the store bought rotisserie chicken.

The chicken was moist and nicely seasoned, although not sticky nor crispy. The leftovers were awesome over salad and then in a sandwich!

text:
I was looking for a new whole chicken recipe, and this looked good! I used around a 4lb bird, and used all the seasoning on it ... only thing I did extra was to rub the chicken down with butter! The chicken cooked for about 4 hours (hour per pound) on a roasting tray so it was just off the bottom of the dish...checked with a meat thermometer at 4 hours and it was done. The house smelled DIVINE all afternoon, and needless to say we ate every last bit of meat! Very moist, and flavorful. I will make this again and like one review said, will make the rub ahead and in a larger quantity! The one change I think I might make is to cut the salt from 4 to 3 ... and to let the chicken season for more than the 4 hours I allowed myself. Great recipe, and its something you can make, pop in the oven and forget while you do other things around the house…it is a no fuss delicious result!

Followed recipe for the spice blend to a T but used it on 6 boneless skinless chicken thighs. As Emeril likes to say "BAM!" -it was great! Just pan-fried them on high to get a nice spice crust. They've got a nice kick to them. Marinated half and cooked the other half immediately. No major difference between the two. I would cut back on the heat just a tad if serving to young kids (mine are 4 and 2 and it was on the edge of being too spicy). Otherwise no changes needed!

text:
This recipe is amazing. I have made it many times, so I figured I needed to give credit where credit is due. The rub is great, don't be scared to keep the spice levels where they are. (An idea- double or quadruple the recipe and save it for the next time. Saves time measuring, and I feel the recipe is a little short for the 7# chicken I cook). The longer you can marinade the chicken, the better it turns out. Let it rest after cooking, the juices run like a river when you cut this thing. Make changes like adding garlic, etc., but if you just follow the directions as written, you will be thrilled with the results.

userID:
12381262
Display Name:
HMG
isPro:

followersCount:

16
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was absolutely delicious! Did not change a thing in terms of ingredients and measurements but I didn't have a whole chicken on hand. Instead I used a large pack of legs and a pack of thighs - about 6 lbs total. I cut an onion, laid big pieces across the bottom of a glass baking dish, and placed the chicken on top. I coated each piece generously with spice mixture, making sure to get under skin and directly on the meat wherever possible. I covered the dish with plastic wrap and stuck in the frig overnight. Next day, I roasted low and slow as stated in the recipe and the result was some of the tastiest, juiciest, most moist chicken I have ever had. I made a simply roux in a separate saucepan and added the pan drippings. I found it to be a little too salty as-is, so I added about 1/3c of water which did the trick - gravy was knock-your-socks off delicious over rice! Can't wait to try bone-in breasts next time! Make this chicken - you won't be disappointed!!

country:
None
text:
I change the servings to 64 and make a mason jar full of the spice (2 cup capacity, I believe).  I use it for everything!  Even add a bit to my chicken noodle soup for an extra kick, or add lots if I'm really congested to clear my sinuses.  I love adding it to drumsticks before throwing them on the grill too.  I do cut the salt down to about 2/3 of what the recipe calls and almost double the paprika and add a bit of the no salt seasoning to compensate, because otherwise it can be a bit salty, especially if you add it to things like pork.  I'm tempted to use it on a turkey with a little sage for thanksgiving, letting it marinate overnight, as the traditional bland turkey has always deterred my family from eating turkey during the holidays.  Yum!

text:
I used this recipe on a chicken which I put in a rotisserie oven.  I made a couple of changes.  I did NOT add the cayenne pepper, I used white pepper but not the black pepper.  I increased the garlic to 1 tsp and I added about 2 tsp of Splenda Brown Sugar mix.  The bit of sweetness from the brown sugar made an amazing difference in the rub.

With those changes this is one of the best rubs I've ever used on a chicken!!

This was fantastic!  I didn't have time to let it sit overnight but did let it sit for a couple of hours in the fridge, uncovered. text:
I read many of the bad reviews to see what might need to be changed, but it looked like most of those reviewers just cooked the chicken too long.  I used a cornish game hen instead of a chicken, put butter under the skin, rubbed with olive oil before I put on the spice rub (I didn't use white pepper or cayenne because my kiddo doesn't like spicy), and cooked it at 375 for an hour.  Turned out great and I will definitely make this again.

userID:

Display Name:
Maralina

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4859661.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First, 5 stars for the cooking method.  The spices/rub could use some additions such as kosher salt, chicken bouillon and fresh ground pepper.  Next, the chicken should be placed in a roasting pan on a rack and liquid should be added to the bottom like broth and red wine.  I also added some sweet peppers in the liquid and on top of the chicken.  We like spicy so I added chipotle peppers in adobo sauce on top and inside and red pepper flake.  During the last 30 minutes, I changed the oven temperature to 275 and let it go an extra 15 minutes, just to be extra safe.  This is not like restaurant rotisserie though and won't be without a rotisserie but it was tender, juicy and quite flavorful with the extras.  Chicken should be basted every 20 minutes or so to keep it juicy.

text:
Wow I loved this chicken!  It has to be the most moist chicken I have ever made.  I made the spice mixture as written but used more than half of it for my one chicken.  I made sure to get a lot of the rub under the skin.  I also put a lemon inside instead of an onion (personal preference).  I also had poor planning when I made this and did not refrigerate overnight or cook for 5 hours.  I cooked covered at 350 for about 3 hours or so (I don't know exactly how long because I was using my meat thermometer) and then uncovered and cooked for amount 20 minutes or so.  This was still fabulous, but next time I will plan better and try marinating.

Hands down - best chicken ever. The spices are perfect and slow cooking for 5 hours in the 250 degree oven is the way to go. The smell of the chicken was driving me bananas for five hours. I couldn't wait to eat! I will try this on just plain chicken breasts and cook for less time when I'm in a hurry on a weeknight sometime-- I think the spice combo is really good.

text:
Just made this recipe and it is nice, but isn't knocking my sox off. I didn't use a whole chicken, I tried pieces as I hate cutting up a whole bird.  Anyway it does have a lovely flavor and is moist.  My cooking time was reduced to 4 hours and I had no drippings for gravy.  Yes I left the skin on and didn't remove any fat so I would have drippings, but no luck.  I think I would go as previous reviews and add a bit of water part way through the cooking. I used smoked paprika and think next time I will try sweet. All in all I would make this again as the cooking method was relaxing.  FYI it didn't turn out sticky as hoped.

text:
Make this all the time but I cook on 450 degrees for 25-30 minutes & then turn down to 375 degrees after adding water mid way high in the pan. Cook for an additional 1 hour until meat is tender & juicy. I also add a bit of coconut palm sugar to even out the taste (most seasoning blends have some form of sugar in it) add more if u like it sweet.

text:
Fabulous! I reduced the salt to only two tsp, one per bird and used 1/2 a sweet onion, 1/4 per bird.  This was so good, my 15 year old requested I make it again the following week for Christmas dinner! 
UPDATE 5/3/14 - I've made this many times since my first review. Today this was a spur of the moment decision, so I didn't have time to let it sit overnight.  I didn't even have 5 hours, so instead I combined it with sliced carrots and a few stalks of celery in a cooking bag.  It was in the oven for 2 hours at 350 degrees.  This time, however, I followed Madicakes' suggestion and added flour to the drippings on the stovetop to make gravy. The seasoning was fantastic - probably the best (and easiest) gravy I've ever made!

text:
I've made this for years!  I absolutely love it!  I do use the white pepper (suprisingly I find it at my local grocery store in the "ethnic" section - Badia brand.)  I seasoned my chicken tonight for Thanksgiving and didn't have onion powder so I used dried minced onion and increased the garlic powder.  Also, I brush my chicken with olive oil before seasoning, and I put carrot, celery, onion and lemon quarters in the cavity.  Chicken (and Turkey) comes out perfect.  I omit the cayenne pepper b/c it's too spicey for kids.  A+ chicken!  It's my go-to seasoning for holiday poultry.

country:
None
text:
This chicken even pleased my husband and he's not a "chicken guy".  It's moist and juicy and very flavorful. One thing I would note might be a reason some folks' results were dry is that the recommended internal temperature for whole chickens is 165 degrees.  If you let it roast all the way to 180 and then the temperature continues to rise while resting, the chicken could be over cooked and dry.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
You can't go wrong with "Low and Slow" cooking chicken like this one. For the person with the dry and tough skin: perhaps you should have your oven calibrated. It is common for chicken skin to get tough when smoking at 225 or lower, but is eliminated when I turn it up a bit. I put mine in a brine overnight to really infuse the flavor and then added the spices before I cooked. It came out wonderful. Great for winters when you can't smoke.

text:
Absolutely fab!!!

I bought my first rotisserie cooker (Ronco 3000), and made this recipe because of the high rating. I didn't have time to marinate the chicken due to being in a bind. I used half of the ingredients on one bird that weighs 5.15 lbs. I skipped stuffing the poultry with the onions, and put in the cooker for about 1.25 to 1.50 hrs. It turned out to be tender, juicy and with the best flavor that is superior to most rotisserie chicken that I have sampled! You can't go wrong with this recipe. It's a keeper!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
We love this recipe! I usually double all the seasoning except the salt and just use what I need to cover the birds. I like to squeeze some lemon juice over the onion before tucking it into the chickens. We get those huge (6-8lb) Perdue roasting chickens with the pop-up timers, keep one for ourselves and give one to family when they're done. Even with the larger size, in my oven they never take 5 hrs to finish - usually 4 to 4.5 hrs, so keep an eye out for the pop-up timer or test with a thermometer to be sure you don't overcook. Thanks for the great recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This chicken in great!! Like many I made substitutions but that's because I didn't have 2 of the ingredients on hand. Instead of onion powder I used minced onion and instead of white pepper I used a pepper medley. The other reviewers had me a little scared about the amount of salt so I used 2 teaspoons of sea salt instead of the 4 tsp. The paprika gives this bird a nice caramel look and  once I made the first cut the rest of the chicken just fell off the bone. The remaining meat will be great on a sandwich! For me once I made this batch I didn't understand how it could season 2 chickens, so I ended up doubling that and using it on ONE chicken. I seasoned the inside, outside and under the skin. Then I stuffed the inside with the quartered onions and 4 cloves of garlic. Twice while baking I drizzled the drippings over the chicken. Flavor flavor flavor is what this chicken is..

5

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy!  This was really good and pretty close to the taste of the rotisserie chicken I've gotten from the store.  As some had suggested, I did cook it in the slow cooker for about 4 hours (over some balls of aluminum foil so the chicken wouldn't sit in the juices). I tried to make it healthier by skinning the chicken first (which was the only hassle of this whole recipe....so that was my choice).  Other than my method, I didn't change a thing about the ingredients.  The chicken really did fall off the bones.  

I also used the really cool feature of changing the serving size (since I just wanted to make one chicken).  That made it simple to know how much of each spice to use ('cause I just didn't feel like doing math on the weekend).  

So glad I found this recipe.  Thanks Sue!

text:
WOW!  This chicken is better than they sell at the store!  We renamed the recipe "Walk Away Chicken" because it's so simple to make:  mix the spices, rub them in, throw the chickens in the oven and walk away!  The only change I made was since I didn't have white pepper, I used 1/2 tsp. of black pepper.  Delicious!  Also, be sure to save the drippings, it makes wonderful chicken noodle soup.

We will make this recipe again and again!

text:
Delicious. This was the best roasted chicken I have made. I did use one chicken, marinated overnight. It took my bird approx. 2 hours and 20 minutes to arrive at 175 degrees. I poured the pan juices in a pan and whisked in 2 T flour and 1 t salt while heating over medium stove. whisk 1+ minute and then add water--while whisking--to ward off lumps a bit at a time until it reaches your desired consistency. Served gravy over the bird and mashed potatoes. YUM!

text:
I was very excited about trying this recipe.  Who doesn't love rotisserie chicken?  Unfortunately, although I followed the recipe to a "T," I just can't recommend it.  While the chicken was moist and tender, it was not any better than any other chicken I have roasted and more trouble.  I will probably use the spice blend again but will rub some under the skin over the breast.  Will, however, probably double the amount.  I won't let it sit in the refrigerator overnight nor will I roast for 5 hours.  I can't help but wonder about the numerous rave reviews.   What did I miss?

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This chicken was incredibly moist and delicious, but it was a bit too salty for me and I'll be sure to cut down on it if I make it again.  I wasn't a huge fan of the cayenne in it, so next time I'll just omit that and use parsley flakes and some italiano seasoning. I also like to make small slits in the skin of the chicken and tuck a slice of garlic in the most meaty of places on the breast and legs. The garlic melts keeps the chicken moist and flavourful as well (for garlic fans) but even without doing this, the chicken is quite moist!

text:
Great recipe!! Just made it today and it was just like a store bought rottiserie chicken but BETTER! For those of you who are short on time, like me, I did not marinate chicken in spices before throwing in the oven. I rubbed chicken with spice recipe (exactly what recipe called for) and put right in the oven at 250 for 3 hours and last hour set temp at 375. I used a 5 1/2 pound chicken and it was done perfectly in 4 hours. I also used drippings for gravy and to coat top of chicken last 45 min or so.

text:
I made one chicken only (5lbs) and modified the spices per my judgement.  The flavoring was good, though it didn't really seep into the chicken.  I was fearful that roasting at such a low temp for so long would dry out the chicken but this was a VERY moist and tender chicken.  My only issue is that there was no pan drippings, there was nothing to baste it with even by the 4th hour! I had to coat it with olive oil to make sure the skin didn't dry out.  I did raise it about a half inch on a roasting rack, maybe that was it? Also, this was not sticky as the name implied. I did think it came out tasty though, but not as expected.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has become a staple menu item in my home. I make the "rub" as I call it in a small container and cover one decent size whole chicken, put it in an oven bag and cook on 250' for 2-3 hours and it is fall apart tender and tastes devine. I also sprinkle the "rub" on skinless thighs and cook @ 375' for 15-20 minutes for a quicker but still delicious meal. If you dont like spicy you may want to lessen the red pepper (cayenne). Also for a healthier recipe use less salt. I keep it as is and do half sea salt and half regular.

text:
Overall a good recipe.  Did one 5 pound chicken and had to turn up the oven to 375 degrees after 2 hours because the temp was not rising on the bird.  The skin wasn't as crispy as I thought it would be, but I covered it with foil for the first 2 hours to prevent drying as other reviewers commented on.  Used the leftover chicken in the "Slow Cooker Chicken Enchilada Soup" recipe on this site, and the spicy flavor of the chicken went well with this recipe.  Expected more from so many 5 star reviews, but I would make this again with a few changes.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe with a family size package of chicken thighs instead of two whole chickens. I washed and removed the skins (interested in lowering the fat) and rubbed the spice mixture all over both sides. Placed the pieces in a glass bowl and put in a chopped medium onion and covered in plastic wrap and placed in the refrigerator overnight. When I arranged the pieces in the baking pan I put a little olive oil on each piece (concerned about the pieces drying without the skin) and baked. It was wonderful! I served with cous cous.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this 100 stars!  I don't eat chicken skin, so I was super tempted to spread the seasoning under the skin as well.  100% unnecessary!!!  Follow the directions.  Wash and dry the chickens (and gosh yes, roast two chickens, not just one), rub the outside of the skin with the seasoning, wrap them up and place them in the fridge overnight.  Somehow (I think it's witchcraft), the seasoning permeates the skin and results in the most flavorful, juicy, amazing chicken ever! The 5 hour cooking time is no big deal.  (Note:  I've made this recipe twice, and it actually took a little more than 5 hours.)  Buy your chickens on sale, stuff your freezer with them, and make this dish often.  The (super flavorful) leftover meat can be used in a thousand different ways.  This is one amazing recipe.

text:
This recipe was excellent! however i was in a time crunch so made it with only 5 small sized chicken breasts and didn't marinate over night. just rubbed it down immediately and let it sit for about 15 mins...   so i had to alter things some what.  i cooked it at 450 for about 30-45 mins.... i used the same rub and cut up an onion and put it in the pan as well with about 4 tablespoons of butter to give it a great crisp and hold the moisture.  then i removed the chicken from the pan and used teh onion and butter sauce at the bottom of the pan for roasted potatoes. i cut them up and seasoned them and tossed them back in the oven at 450 for 40 mins.  PERFECTION!

this chicken was absolutely amazing. i turned up the oven to about 265 or so the first couple hours because i put it in a bit late...BIG mistake. it would have been wonderful the way directions said, except only 4 1/2 hours! in effect, it turned out a little dry after only 4 1/2 hours but wouldn't have, i bet, with my "correction". very very juicy and full of flavor! next time maybe a little less salt but either way it will be great. definitely a keeper!!!

text:
This is exactly what I've been looking for.  I have a rotisserie oven and have tried chicken in it several times and it has never been great!  This was great!  I followed the recipe except for the following...  I omitted white pepper, cut the cayenne and black pepper in half.  At 7:30 this morning I removed the giblets and rinsed and dried the (4 lb.) chicken.  I then rubbed it with olive oil and covered the inside and out with the spices and placed it back in the fridge until 9:45 when i placed it in the rotisserie and 2 hours later it was cooked to perfection!  I did try to put the onion inside, but most of it fell out during cooking.  I also collected the drippings and put them in a sauce pan and added a small can of chicken broth and 1 1/2 tsp. of cornstarch and brought it to a boil until thickened.  Mashed some potatoes and it was a fantastic meal!  Will have again soon since my picky hubby loved it!

text:
Wow!   I've been making this chicken recipe for years with slight variations.  I only use 1 tsp. of salt, 1/2 tsp. of onion powder, and 1/4 tsp. of white pepper and no black pepper.  I add a tsp. of marjoram & 1/2 tsp. poultry seasoning.  It is the best!  The meat just falls off the bones and makes the best chicken broth that is definitely worth freezing to use later in soups and to saute vegetables.  I cooked 3-4 chickens at a time and freeze in 2-3 cups freezer quart bags to use in many recipes in a quick snap.

text:
This Easter we had a rotisserie chicken contest between my husband and I with my family as the judges. Although no one would come out and say it it was very clear that this recipe beat the chicken done in our GF Rotisserie Cooker. I followed someones suggestion and cooked it for four hours and turned it up for a short time in the middle. I also added water to the bottom of my roasting pan and basted the chicken occasionally. I halved the cayenne pepper to make it less spicy. Since I only did one bird it worked out ok, but if I was to do two I would double the seasoning mixture. Everyone said the chicken was nice and juicy and had a nice flavor. We will be making this many times.

userID:
747565
Display Name:
MakeItWork
isPro:
False
followersCount:
14

168

323

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/570354.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, my 25 cents: 4.5 stars cuz of salt called for but...Best chicken ever! I mix up a large spice bottle of spice rub although I use way less salt. You can always add more salt but you can't remove it :) My method is: I mix 3 T of butter, 1 tsp of seasoning + a tsp of lemon juice. I place a blob under the breast skin and spread it around by rubbing top of skin with my hands. Then place on sheets of plastic wrap I have ready & liberally shake spice mix all over skin and wrap that baby up. Much better left in fridge overnight but it's still darn good after 4 hours hang time. I bake 1 - 4 to 5lb bird & it turns out perfect after 4 hrs (last 30 minutes at 350). I start with breast side down & flip it over midway. Allow to rest for 10 to 15 mins afterwards. I use crushed cloves of garlic, sprigs of fresh rosemary and chunks of lemon in cavity vs onion. I also add 1-1/2 cups of chicken stock to pan since my chicken is elevated while roasting. Makes great gravy for mashed taters and moping dinner rolls in. When whole chickens on sale, I buy 2 or 3, get them seasoned and wrapped up and freeze for another time. Well, this chicken isn't necessarily 'sticky' but I like the low/slow roasting process and can control how I want seasoned vs buying a premade one at store.

5

text:
I guess I am in the minority on this one. Cooking method is pretty good. Chicken was moist. The skin never crisped up -- which is part of why I like rotisserie chicken. I turned up the heat in the oven and tried to crisp it up at the end. It helped. The flavor was not great. WAY too much onion. Blech. Other than that, honestly, little flavor. Overall I was disappointed. Might make some adjustments and try again another day. Meanwhile -- carcass is in a pot making chicken stock (so all is not lost).

This was amazing! I only made one chicken but used the same amount of spice as the recipe called for, so I doubled the spice. I rubbed all over and under the skin. In addition to stuffing with onions, I also stuffed with about 3 chopped garlic cloves. I only needed to roast for 4 hours.  This was seriously an awesome dinner. city:

country:
None
text:
Oh, yeah. That's the ticket. Deli chicken no more, I'm going to this recipe from now on. My modifications (we always have some, don't we): I added 1/2 tsp smoked paprika, doubled the garlic powder and used about 1 tsp less salt. And I added two cloves garlic in each chicken cavity. Otherwise followed the recipe and will make this again and again, using my oven rotisserie spit. Thanks for a great recipe. UPDATE: I no longer have that handy oven, so I use my brand-new convection oven. Still cut back the salt, now by half actually, and double the garlic powder, use ground thyme, and man, I'm so glad someone reminded me of this recipe. I'm just now licking my lips from enjoying it tonight. As for the salt content, as a friend from here once said: If you don't like that much salt, use less salt! So that's what I do here, and I'll state again, no more supermarket rotisserie chickens for me. This one is as easy as using my Crockpot. Thanks again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked the flavor of this chicken and I will definitely make it again, HOWEVER, about an hour into cooking I checked the chicken and the skin was quite dry, so I decided to add some olive oil to it.  I didn't have 2 whole chickens so I cooked 1 whole chicken and some wings.  The wings turned out wonderful after brushing them with the olive oil, but the whole chicken not so much.  The skin that was face up looked absolutely delicious, but was tough as leather.  I guess I thought of the olive oil too late. :-(  The bottom of the chicken was moist and luckily I cooked it breast side down.  So all and all, the only change I would make to this recipe is to brush the chicken with olive oil and/or cover it while cooking, uncovering in the end to brown it.

userID:

Display Name:
Lori Newmann
isPro:

9

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7710694.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous! A definite keeper. While one of the keys to this recipe is the slow roasting, the last time I made this, I ran into a time conflict. Due to necessity, I took a tip from America's Test Kitchen and roasted this at 500 degrees for 15 minutes on 1 side (1 wing side up), then turned the chicken over to the other wing side up for 15 more minutes, then put it breast side up for the additional cooking time. I then turned the oven down to 350 for about 30 minutes. The higher up-front temp browned my bird giving it nice color and a boost on cooking time. I then turned down the temp to the 250 called for in the recipe for an additional 2 hours. It was wonderful. Not as fall-apart fabulous as when cooked for 5 hours according to the directions here but an excellent option if you run short on time.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2009-12-03T12:20:02.92

text:
4.5 stars.  Very easy to make.  The only thing I did differently was to place garlic slits under the breast skin and in the cavity.  A 5 lb. chicken took 3-3.5 hours to roast.  I aded chicken stock to the pan juices along with a butter/flour roux with a little sage for gravy.  Plenty of leftovers too.

The texture of the chicken is spot on.  But you really need to watch the roasting time as mine was done in nearly 2.5 hours. The next time I toned down the garlic and onion powder, upped the paprika and time, and it mellowed out the salitness beautifully.  Happy cooking!

This was good. This recipe is great if only for the cooking method, I think you can adjust the seasoning based on preference/necessity. I used 2 tsp salt, 2 tsp paprika, 1 tsp thyme, 1 tsp rosemary, and 1 tsp garlip powder for 1 (4 lb)chicken. It was done 4 hours, juicy and with a crunchy skin with no basting, oil or butter. Drippings made great gravy.

text:
Oh my. This is simply the best chicken I have ever cooked! I have never rated a recipe on All Recipes until now. I just had to thank Sue for posting this. I am excited for my family to come home and eat this! This is when cooking is fun. How can something so unbelievably easy be so good? I seasoned the chickens last night. I followed the recipe as closely as I could, but didn't have all of the ingredients,  so I used Cajun Seasoning, and it turned out incredible. I didn't have any plastic wrap or bags either (what kind of cook am I?!), so I put them in the pan I was roasting them in, and covered tight with 2 layers of foil. For the life of me, I cannot fathom how the previous poster thought this chicken needed more flavor. The flavor and color were both out of this world. I would give this recipe 10 or more stars if I could! My little 5 year old grandson got first dibs on a chicken leg, and he gobbled the whole thing up...the chicken was so tender, all the meat just fell off the bone, so he ate it legless. I will use this recipe over and over again.

userID:
2644123
Display Name:
DianaGV
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
183
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the chickens last night. I followed the recipe exactly so i could give it a fair rating. My chickens were 4.60lb and 4.30lb. I prepared the rub as is, but added more garlic powder as other reviewers did and i didn't put white pepper. The rub was really good but i could have used more of it. Next time i will make a bigger batch. I also put half a lemon in the cavity. TRY IT it's delicious that way. Why 4 stars then? After 4 hrs. of cooking, there were a lot of drippings so i was going to baste the chickens. I checked the internal temperature and it read 200 degrees!!! I was very disappointed. Why don't i rate it one star then? The breasts were a little dry but actually not unedible, the thighs were good! If you take it out at 170 degrees like you should (NOT 180) they would probably be quite moist and delicious! Check the temp. after a couple of hours of cooking please. Also, basting made a difference with the color and texture of the skin. The gravy was absolutely the best one i've ever had. Make two chickens at once, pull the meat off the leftovers and use for chicken salad, tortilla soup...you can put it in a ziploc and freeze it. Use the bones and onions to make chicken broth! Easy and money saving recipe!

text:
I didn't have any cayenne pepper or onion powder. Instead, I rubbed a tsp of hot sauce on the rinsed bird and then rubbed the seasoning mix atop that. Placed some onion slices on the top, and shoved into the oven.  Didn't marinate, and it turned out DELICIOUS. Next time I'll try marinating, but I just didn't have the time. So if you're hesitant to try this because of the addt'l time, don't worry about it!  Per another review, I made gravy using the fat drippings and a can of chicken broth (used flour instead of corn starch), and it was AMAZING.  Made a stunning dinner.

Deelish chicken!  I didn't have an onion, so I used dry minced onion inside the cavity.  I also would use 1/2 the salt and cut the cooking time by 1hr for a 5lb chicken. I cooked it for 5.5hrs and it was yummy and falling off the bone, but I would have liked to been able to cut it, instead of shred it!  I used the entire amount of seasonings on one 5lb chicken. I rubbed under the skin as well as on top.  And I only marinated it for about 1.5hrs.  My family loved it, minus it being a little on the salty side, which is why next time I'll use half the amount of salt.

text:
This chicken was fabulous!!!  I did melt some butter and put on the chicken before I put on the spices.  I added a lemon and some fresh rosemary to the cavity.  I could marinate for about 3 hours and I cooked it for 5 hours.  It was a 5 lb chicken.  I increased the temp to 300 for the last 30 minutes.  It was so pretty we didn't want to eat it.  It was also very tender and juicy.  I will definately roast my chickens like this from now on.  I also added about 1 cup of chicken boullon to the pan and the last 2 hours I added some baby carrots.....
Update....I feel like 5 hours is too long.  I made this today and only cooked for 4 hours.  It was so much better and so tender.  My husband only complaint was the skin was not crisp enough so next time I make this I will cook for 3 1/2 hours and put it under the broiler to crisp up the skin....since it is just my husband and I, I just cook 1 chicken

cooks4forty

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/239460.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
There's been enough said about this delicious recipe, but I wanted to share my experience translating this to a turkey.  I made a 13 pounder using this recipe.  I made one and a half batch of the rub, and probably could have doubled it.  With the straight math of time per pound, it came out to be over 15 hours.  However, mine was done (internal temp. of 180) at 11 hours.  At ten hours it would probably been ready at 170 (which is when I would have pulled it out for carryover).  I covered it and let it coast at 170 until mealtime and it was still delicious, maybe a little less juicy than it would have been had I timed it better.  The only drawback - the pan juices dried out, so I had no dripping for gravy.  I still would recommend this for a turkey, but be prepared to play with it a little.  The rub is absolutely delicious!

text:
After reading through most of the reviews, I gave this recipe a try.  This also was the CLOSEST I have ever stuck to recipe.  In fact, the only thing I did was cut the salt to 3 tablespoons and omit the white pepper because as one reviewer said "who has white pepper"? lol..Anyway, this was so easy to do and I had my two (4lb) chickens seasoned and wrapped in about 15 mins.  I refrigerated them for just under 5 hrs. and cooked them at temp stated for just over 4 hrs.  That's when they hit the 170 mark. The aroma in the house was incredible and the taste was excellent!  My son thought it was a tad too spicy so next time I'll reduce the cayenne a bit but everything else was great!  It seemed like a perfect spice blend. I will also do this on a 6-8lb roaster instead of the smaller chickens next time just for ease and personal preference. Enjoy!

text:
OMG, what a chicken recipe! Flavor was incredible even though I didn't marinate the bird for more than an hour. Note to self "read the recipe in full before making it". Even though I was pressed for time to make this so quickly it was as promised ~ fall off the bone good, and better than a store bought bird! My husband and I NEVER eat the skin from chicken, but this recipe made it impossible to resist. I mean who eats leftover chicken and the skin cold the next day out of the fridge? It was so good we plan to make this small indulgence twice a month. I am making this for company next week because I feel the recipe can't fail me. The spices were just right in this rub, just the right kick without being overpowering. I plan to try this rub on ribs and tri-tip. In a word, this recipe is a "keeper". Thank you for this post:)

text:
I'm so glad I put off buying that chicken rotisserie I've been dying for. This method is so easy and it tastes better than what you buy from the store. I did inject my chicken with broth every hour and throw in a couple cloves of garlic into each cavity along with the onion. Perfectly moist. For an even moister more flavorful bird cook it upside down, the fat from the dark meat will flow through the white meat before draining out resulting in super moist white meat.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/111665.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I thought that this recipe was very good; the only thing that I didn't understand was how the chicken was supposed to be "sticky". I adapted the recipe to my own needs, using 3 large bone-in, skin-on chicken breasts and half the amount of the original seasonings called for. I also replaced the white pepper with lemon pepper- does anyone ever have white pepper in their kitcen? I placed the chicken breasts on a bed of onions, celery, carrots and lemon wedges and then added about a cup of chicken broth to the roasting pan. I let the dish sit in the frige overnight and then baked it all at 250 for about 3 hours. The chicken was very moist and flavorful and I am looking forward to the leftovers, that's for sure! I would like to play with this recipe, adding some fresh herbs to the mix next time and maybe getting rid of the lemon wedges and lemon pepper. Anyway, it's a great recipe and I will make it again!

text:
Come to mamma. First time roasting a chicken low and slow, but man! won't be my last. Best whole roast chicken I ever made. The seasoning mix is excellent. Omitted the white pepper since I didn't have any otherwise kept to the recipe. Next time I will crank the cayenne a tad. I had one 6 pounder, but didn't adjust the seasoning amounts and rubbed the bird the night before and left overnight in the fridge. I stuffed with a lemon and garlic in addition to the onion. Roasted until thigh got to 170, I think that was somewhere between 4 and 5 hours. Be sure to make gravy from these drippings! Num! Not sure why recipe is called "Sticky" though.

text:
I have not roasted a chicken so slowly before, and honestly, I am not sure it is necessary.  Typically I roast at 350 for just 2.5 hours or so....this recipe did turn out well, but I think you can save some time and maybe energy by roasting it for a shorter time at a higher temp.  Also, I recommend using a pre-made spice rub liek Mrs. Slyvia's chicken rub or Adobo chicken flavor with pepper.  Just some suggestions!  The recipe WAS good.  Be careful because the birds put off a lot of juice if you use a corning baking dish.

text:
That was the best chicken I have ever made.  I only used one chicken so I halved the ingredients and cooked the chicken for about 3 1/2 hours.  The meat was falling off the bone and very good.  I also added one can of chicken broth to the bottom of the roasting pan.  After the chicken cooked I drained the drippings and cooked broth into a saucepan, quickly whisked in 1/2 c. of flour and let thicken.  It was an amazing gravy!  I will definitely be making this again in the future!!

Hello Everyone,  I made this exactly as printed.  It was very tasty, however, it was not sticky or even crispy.  The bottom of my roaster had a lot of water in it even though I had dilligently dried the chicken inside and out before putting the rub in and outside.  The only thing I can think of that would have caused this is that the chicken was not FRESH and that it has been previously FROZEN by the supermarket and had not been labled as such.  I will make it again as we enjoyed it.  Today, I will make sandwiches from the leftovers.  I want the next time to be sticky and crunchy.  If anyone else had this problem, I would appreciate a response.  Many thanks,  Beverly Jane

text:
Wow! I was really wondering how good this recipe would be... nearly perfection. I actually did this for Christmas dinner, and since there were only five of us, I made two smaller chickens. I rubbed both, placed in saran wrap, cooked one the next day and waited until the next day to cook the second. They were both delicious, even though the second chicken I did not have time to "slow cook", I cooked for about 1 1/2 hours on 350. Both cooking times turned out fantastic, although the slow cooking method was slightly more moist... I am not sure if this has more to do with the slower cooking or the fact the second chicken sat in the fridge for an extra day. Highly recommend this recipe. Perfect for a weekend day

userID:
2345797
Display Name:
babychase3
isPro:

followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
38
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3788006.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OH-MY-GOODNESS!!!  This was absolutely delicious!  I have never made a whole chicken before and, I must say, I outdid myself!  Thanks for the detailed reviews everyone.  From my readings, I only used 1 5lb. chicken, cut the salt in half, and I didn't add any onions or other spices into the cavity aside from the rub.  I also omitted the garlic powder because I didn't have any on hand.  I made up for it by using garlic salt instead of plain salt.  I also sprinkled in some Tony Chachere's Creole Seasoning and ground ginger.  I let my bird marinate for about 2 1/2 hours in a Ziploc bag.  I baked it in a roasting pan for about  3 1/2 hours on 250, with the last half hour at 350.  I only basted in once while it baked, squirting small amounts of squeezable margarine on top and off to the side.  When I took the chicken out of the oven, I basted it with the juices at the bottom of the roasting pan.  It was brown and crispy on the outside and, as promised, absolutely tender and juicy inside!  It was almost too easy to carve; I couldn't even hold the meat between my fork and knife to get it out in one piece!  I served it with cheddar and bacon scalloped potatoes, green beans, and salad.  It was soooo yummy...

text:
I suppose I'm rating the method rather than the whole recipe itself- I didn't make the seasoning mixture to rub on the chicken. Instead, I used 1 tsp of lemon pepper seasoning and 1 tsp of spanish adobo. It came out wonderful! We haven't dug into the legs yet, but the breast was moist and flavorful. It seems that cooking at such a low heat seals the skin on the outside of the bird to keep all the juices in. Yum!

EXCELLENT!!!! I've made this chicken twice now and we love it. My boyfriend just about ate the whole chicken by himself. I kept the spices just as the recipe called for. I only make one chicken and add all the spice on that one chicken. I coat the chicken with olive oil before putting the spices on. I also took a few pats of butter and coated them in the spices, and put that under parts of the skin. This recipe is a keeper for sure. Also I only cook my chicken for 4hrs instead of 5hrs.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I quartered the salt but otherwise kept all the other seasonings the same. I rubbed it into a 4 lb chicken, and wrapped it tightly overnight. I also stuffed the cavity with 1 quartered onion and 3 cloves garlic.
I slow roasted as the recipe indicated, except I poured 1/2 cup chicken broth over the bird and brushed the skin w/  melted butter before cooking. When the chicken was done, I poured the drippings into a saucepan, whisked in 1 T flour, and cooked up some delicious gravy. The meat was tender, moist, and falling off the bone!

text:
YUMMY YUM YUM!!  I don't cook roast chicken very often because I haven't found a really good recipe yet, but now I have!  The only change I made to the recipe is that I doubled the seasoning.  I added half of the seasoning to buttermilk, mixed it up good and marinated the chicken overnight in it.  (I had some on hand left over from a cake recipe and thought how good fried chicken is when marinated in buttermilk and decided to give it a try for this recipe)  In the morning early, I took it out of the buttermilk, rinsed it off and continued with the recipe as written.   I cooked Broccoli in Roast Chicken Drippings (from allrecipes.com by Kristin) in my pan drippings and it was perfect.  This is a keeper!

text:
This was OK. I expected more after reading the reviews. I don't think the chicken was infused with flavor as much as I expected. Also, and this is the biggest reason that I'm giving it three stars, it took WAAAY shorter than five hours too cook. I bet it could be done in three; I don't know for sure because I bumped it down to 200 when it became apparent that it was cooking faster than I expected. This could be a big problem for people who have a scheduled dinner time, like we do. It really messes plans up, to have such a big discrepancy in the time. I wish the recipe would be modified to reflect that.

Fabulous chicken.  Moist and flavorful.  I followed the recipe pretty close except for a few things.  One, I brined the chicken the night before (which cut down the cook time by one hour). text:
Disappointing. I will buy a store bought rotisserie chicken next time. I rubbed the seasoning under and on top of the skin; I allowed the seasonings to penetrate the bird overnight while wrapped in plastic wrap.  I stuffed the cavity with onions (no garlic but will next time).  The next day, I put the chicken on top of an oven rack inside a roaster but did not baste it; the chicken was still tender and moist  without basting.  I am disappointed with the lack of flavor; I did not change the ingredients and even included the white pepper although others omitted it but I still think this recipe was missing the KICK that I expected.  The cooking method deserves the five stars.  That's why I compromised with four stars--3 for seasonings and 5 for the cooking method. I will use the cooking method again just not the seasoning mix.

userID:
236293
Display Name:
DiaNeuroSci
isPro:

5

19

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best recipe I've ever found online.  I've been making this chicken at least once a month for about two years and it never fails.  I generally use organic, free range chicken and only one, not two, as the recipe calls for and it blows grocery store pre-made chickens and Boston Market chicken out of the water--it's just that good.  Definitely don't rush it, leave it in the fridge at least 8-12 hours.  No changes or adjustments are needed but alterations because you're out of something will be fine--if you don't have white pepper, cut it out or use black/red.  I also always stuff onions or apples or whatever I have in the cavity for extra flavor.  I've used butter under the skin thinking it would be even better but it's not necessary, the recipe is perfection as is.  UPDATE: Last Thanksgiving I used this recipe on my turkey and it was just as good, adjust the cooking time for your size bird and you're good to go!

I prepared one 4.5lb chicken, stuffed if full of onion and garlic.  I sealed it in a Foodsaver bag for 12 hours and it cooked to 170 degrees in 3.5 hours.  It was very easy, juicy, and made the house smell divine.  We ate it clean and the remains are simmering for homemade chicken stock.  
I'll make this again for sure!

text:
This was so easy, moist and full of flavor. I cut the recipe in half, using  one 4 1/2 lb. chicken. I rubbed the spices under and on top of the skin, marinated for 5 hours in the fridge and slow-roasted at 250 for 4 1/2 hours, basting the chicken with the pan juices throughout. I also added a few garlic cloves and chopped shallot to the onion in the cavity. It is so easy to make and wonderful! The bones make a great broth as well. Will add this to regular rotation. YUM!

text:
I made this exactly as recipe stated - (except I only made 1 large chicken) I  let it marinate for 24 hours - Let it slow cook in a large roaster for 4 hours - then basted it with butter to get it to brown and cooked another hour. It was so tender the meat fell of the bone and the chicken was SOOO MOIST - It was DELICIOUS!

text:
I tried this recipe after a failed attempt to cook a whole chicken a few months ago...it was great!  My husband ( who is a HUGE chicken fan) said it was the best chicken he'd ever had.  I have to agree...even the white meat was super moist and tender.  I cooked it in an electric roaster instead of in the oven, but otherwise followed the recipe exactly.  I think one of the keys is cooking at a low temp for a long time.  I'm planning to strip off all the remaining meat and make another chicken dish later in the week!  What a great meal!  (And I got the chicken on sale for 69c/lb!)

text:
Loved it!!! I seasoned the chickens in the morning and threw it in the oven at 2:30 pm, baked it at 350 degrees for an 1 1/2 hours with the breast side down, and it came out moist and tender. I did add chicken broth to the bottom of the pan and made some gravy with the drippings, oh my goodness, it was great! I had to make dinner for some neighbors and they loved it. Plus my boys ate like crazy. Thank you for this recipe. **Also, the local store was having a sale on whole chickens, so I seasoned the chickens and froze them, without the onion. When I get ready to cook them I will thaw them and then add in the onion. Thanks again for this wonderful recipe.

Didn't have the patience to slow roast but I did use the seaoning mixture and double wrapped and put in the fridge for a few hours. I also put a tablespoon of chopped garlic inside with cavity with tghe onion, put a few tablespoons butter under the skin, topped the bird with a few strips of bacon and put two cups of stock in the pan to help start a gravy. Best chicken I've ever made. Next time I'll think a bit more ahead and do the slow roast.

text:
UPDATE -I  I can't believe the bad reviews this gets...if you have a dry or salty chicken you obviously haven't adjusted the time/recipe  properly for one chicken. I have marinated  the chicken overnight for this and done it off the cuff, and it's NEVER failed. I first reviewed this in 2009- I'm still using this recipe now, in 2016 on a at least monthly basis. In fact, I always have this seasoning on hand in a jar. I don't even measure it now, it's all just muscle memory,lol...**ORIGINAL REVIEW**  This was so yummy!! I came across this recipe a while ago, and decided the other day at kind of the last minute to do a roasted chicken, and I remembered that I had wanted to try this recipe...anyway, long story short, I skipped the marinating step and the chicken was still delicious, although next time I will marinate it as the recipe calls for. I only cooked one chicken, so 5 hours was  longer than needed to cook it, so I just set my oven to warm... I roasted some garlic and made a shallot and roasted garlic gravy from the pan drippings, and served it with hoppin' john and kicken' collard greens from this website. I will definately be making this again!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I used two whole chickens cut up.  Instead of mixing all of the ingredients, I put each ingredient on the chicken individually.  That eliminated the chicken from being so salty. I did use season salt instead of just regular salt. I used meat tenderizer, accent, and mccormicks salt free all purpose seasoning as well. I marinated for 1day and a half due to circumstances. I put the temperature at 300 degrees gas stove equivalent to 275 electric stove. I added an onion.  I baked for one hour on one side, turned over and baked for one hour on the other side.  It seemed like too much pepper once I tasted it out of the oven. The next day all the flavors took and it was delicious.  Not Rotisserie. But great flavor.  Very tender.

text:
1/2 paprika, no cayenne, double garlic powder. two pats of butter in spices in skin. 3 pound chicken perfect for Lauren and I with a little left over-mostly dark meat. 1 hour on high in crockpot followed by 10 hours on low. Fab! Grill: 3 pound chicken with spice rub, no onions. pats of butter on breasts. Melted 1 c butter 2 tbsp garlic salt, 2 tbsp paprika. put in center of roaster. save some to baste once on grill. med heat 1 to 1/2 hours. (3 on low). For 2- 1 hr on med and 1 on low

userID:
1541439
Display Name:
kikadee
isPro:

1

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/162.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First of all, I was fortunate enough to get my hands on a free-range, organic chicken raised by neighbours, and this slow-roasting method cooked it to perfection. All four stars are for that! The rub was ... alright. Tasty enough, but the end result was nowhere near "sticky," like you'd get with a marinade/glaze. I followed other reviewers' advice and stuffed the chicken with quartered onions and minced garlic, nicely flavouring the pan juices from which I made gravy. I also set the chicken to roast on a bed of potatoes and carrots, but here's a lesson I learned from this experience: vegetables should be in small chunks, or sliced thin, because they just don't cook through at that low heat when they're large and chunky, which was my mistake. I'd follow this recipe again for the low-and-long cooking style, but I'd try a different preparation method.

userID:
1344998
Display Name:
Joelsjen
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/422168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was super easy and really yummy.  After reading the reviews, I did not know what to think, especially about the cooking time.  I decided to do exactly as the recipe states for the first time around.  The only thing I changed was the onion powder.  I did not have any so I used dehydrated onions which I crunched up a bit.  What I would change when doing it again is cut down the salt by 1 tsp.  The chicken was not salty until you ate the little pieces in the bottom of the roaster at the end.  I just don't think chicken is a meat that really needs much salt.  My chickens were really juicy and had I had the cornstarch or flour (I am not at my own home), I would have made the gravy others suggested.  I think because it was so juicy, it did not really have the "sticky" that rotisserie usually has.  The thing I like most about this recipe is that it is so easy and seemingly fool-proof.  I fixed it and put it in the fridge at 10 pm.  I got up at 5am and put it in the oven.  It was done in perfect time for me to leave at 10:30 am for a pot-luck lunch.  I was worried about the flavors not going through the chicken skin, since the recipe does not say to remove the skin (which makes it all the more easy), but the flavors were wonderful!  They certainly permiated the skins!  I had quite a few compliments on this dish.  It is certainly worth a try!

text:
Phenominal recipe! This is the first whole chicken I've made, and it came out perfect. I used a smaller chicken and just used an internal thermometer to see when it reached 180 degrees in the thickest part of the thigh. The meat really did fall off the bone. I followed the recipe almost exactly, but needed more spice mixture to rub on. Also, i added minced garlic in the cavity with the onion. It sat wrapped in the fridge for a whole day, which i think added to the flaor. I took another's advice and seperated the skin and coated inside of it with butter seasoned with the mixture. My boyfriend is obsessed with this recipe. After he had it, 2 whole chickens showed up in the fridge the next week! Wonder why.. :) I used the leftover chicken for chicken and dumplings and it was spectacular.

text:
Good chicken, but to me only worth three stars because I feel it was not exactly as described.  (I made the recipe exactly as written.) I didn’t find the flavor or texture to be “restaurant style”.  (Not that it matters, but it also was not "sticky".) I agree with another poster in that I do not think it is the spice mixture that makes the bird good, but the slow cooking that does.  I believe you can use your favorite chicken roasting flavoring and still have the chicken come out very juicy and tender by slow cooking it.  However, I found that the plastic poultry cooking bags worked even better than this slow cooking technique, and for much less time.  My chickens always falls off the bone, yet are crispy on the outside using that method.

userID:
1302669
Display Name:
BroncosFan
isPro:

followersCount:

favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/220698.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my favorite way to make a chicken. It's delicious although the skin has never come out "sticky." I usually use one chicken and just sprinkle with paprika, pepper and a little garlic salt or garlic powder (I don't follow the exact measurements and omit the salt). Before placing in the oven, I drizzle it with a little olive oil (sometimes I use butter). The cooking times are perfect and I have had no problems with dryness and have made this more than a dozen times (for those who have, just start checking the chicken after 4 hours). Lately, I make this without refrigerating overnight - just season and pop it in the oven and it still comes out GREAT! I do pour off any bottom juices and add this to some chicken broth for gravy. After everyone has picked it clean, I make homemade chicken soup or chicken salad (if there are enough leftovers). This is a very tasty and economical meal. Thanks!!

This is a great recipe.  The spices made it through to the meat, so even without eating the skin, I could taste the flavor.  I used the same quantities of spices (except white pepper, which I didn't have) for just one 4-pound chicken, and it seemed like the right amount.  My husband liked the texture of the skin better than other roasted chicken I have made and requested that I make this again.  I may try using higher heat and a shorter cooking time to see how that turns out.

text:
This is the best roasted chicken I've ever made. I used double the seasoning  (minus thyme) on and under the skin overnight, drizzled on olive oil, and placed the chicken on quartered potatoes. About half-way through the cooking time, I turned the chicken over. I added another fifteen minutes at 350 degrees F to get the  bird's temperature to 180 degrees. Unless I get a larger slow cooker, this will be the only way I roast chicken.

text:
My biggest problem with this recipe is the fact it does not come out "sticky" at all like a rotisserie chicken is supposed to.  I looked over the reviews and couldn't find anything except maybe add a little butter to the chicken.  I searched other recipes on the web and a lot of them called for honey and either lemon or lime juice to be basted on the chicken.  This seems to make sense.  I wonder if this spice mix would work with some sort of liquid base like I mentioned applied on top.  Anyone have experience with this?

Also, as much as I liked the spice mix, it calls for WAY too much salt.  In fact if I hadn't cooked it myself I would have thought someone was playing a joke on me.  Cut in half at least.

text:
This is THE BEST CHICKEN EVER!   I am a terrible cook, I  admit it, and meats are the most difficult for me to do. I have problems with overcooking and things coming out to rubbery and chewy.
 
Unfortunately my daughter requested chicken for Christmas dinner, so I decided to give this recipe a try. The recipe was *very* easy, and the chicken turned out to be exceptional! Very 'sticky' and moist, as the title implies.  

I couldn't find some of the spices that were needed, so I used the McCormick's mesquite seasoning blend, but followed the rest of the recipe precisely.  The house smelled delicious and the slow cooking made this fail-proof - I highly recommend this dish to anybody who likes chicken.

userID:
36207
Display Name:
JUSTCYN
isPro:
False
followersCount:
27
followingCount:
0

154
favoritesCount:
51
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/228953.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow! There were so many ways to roast whole chicken! I didn’t like the high heat recipes or their spice themes. I didn’t really want to slow roast either but I went all the way trying to make this as written. I never did get the “sticky” reference but even so, this chicken did come out wonderfully juicy and tender for me. I halved the spices and made only one bird. Sprinkling the spices on looks perfect but when you actually rub them around on the skin it looks like you are rubbing it all off. I just tried to distribute it as best I could. I only had 3 hours to marinate. Surprisingly this method does infuse the meat of the whole chicken with a nice mild flavor you can definitely taste but doesn’t overpower. I did broil 15 mins. at the end to crisp the skin. It still wasn’t very crispy but I don’t care much about eating the skin anyway. The broiling did give it the rotisserie appearance though. The juices make very tasty gravy, don’t throw them out! I’ll make this recipe again.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2006-05-03T13:27:09.873
helpfulCount:
0

text:
This is the first time I've every roasted a chicken. It couldn't have been easier. I left it in the oven until the meat thermometer reached 180 degrees, about 4 hours. The meat was very moist and the skin was light & crispy, not greasy like on some store-bought chicken. I will definitely make this again and again.

text:
WOW!!!  This was an awsome chicken recipie!!!  I halved the recipie to make only one chicken.  I used 1 1/4 tsp of seasoned salt instead of 2tsp and I thought it was perfect that way.  I used 1/2 tsp of Garlic powder and 1/4 tsp Basil.  I also didn't use an onion in the cavity because I didn't have any on hand.  This was DELICIOUS.  I cooked it for 4 hours and made a gravy with the drippings.  The chicken was so tender and the gravy and chicken were flavorful, so this will DEFINATLY be made again in my house!!

text:
This is a great recipe!  We received the Junior Showtime Grill Rotisserie Oven as a gift, and this recipe is perfect for it!  I halved the recipe for 1 whole chicken, put it in the rotisserie oven, and it's ready in about 1 hour.  I had a hard time keeping the onions inside the cavity (not great at tying the chicken, and they kept falling out while rotating).  But a savory  juicy chicken.  I've since just pre-mixed rotisserie spices to keep on hand, and roast chicken legsthighs in the rotisserie's grill basket, omitting the onions.  My husband and I love it.  Thanks for sharing!

text:
This recipe works. You could probably rub almost any combination of spices on chicken and cook it for 4 to 5 hours at 250 and it would be moist and yummy. But this one and these spices make a wonderful  flavor. If you are careful to monitor the chicken after about 3 1/2 hours, so it doesn't overcook, it will be flavorful, moist and delicious. I served my dinner guests with confidence and they enjoyed it very much. Leftovers were used for salad, pasta and sandwiches. This is a family basic.

text:
Oh my gosh, this was so good! I halved the recipe and only did one chicken. Beforehand, I separated the skin from the meat and oiled (olive oil) the meat so it'd be more moist. I also put the marinade/rub on the meat as well as the skin. It could have been spicier for my taste, but it had a great texture and flavor. Roasting it at a low temp. for 5 hours was a great way to cook it! I'll do that from now on when roasting a chicken.

text:
I must say, the cooking method makes the chicken come out FABULOUS!!! I placed mine on a wire rack in my roasting pan so that it wouldn't be too soggy on the botton. The skin was perfect (it's my favorite) not too crunchy, not too chewy, not soggy. The chicken could have been cut apart with a butterknife, it was sooo tender. I loved this recipe so much that I made it twice before the weekend was over (once with this spice mix, the next upon request with a barbecue spice powder mix) they were both so yummy (honestly though, I liked the bbq mix better)!! Thank You Sue!!!  

P.S. It was my first time roasting a whole chicken ;)

Update -- I made this for Christmas dinner and it was a huge hit.  My granddaughter said it was the best chicken she ever ate.  My DIL who usually eats like a bird went back for seconds.

text:
Another for our Top Ten list of favorites!  It was absolutely delicious! I followed the recipe exactly, except I didn't have white pepper and used 1 tsp of Lawry's Seasoned Pepper.  Chickens marinated 4 hrs and cooked exactly 5 hrs.  They did fall off the bones, even the breast bone.
Unfortunately, in spite of absolutely awesome flavor, my chickens were very dry!  Both chickens were over 4lbs, so this was totally unexpected...I need to get an oven thermometer, because I will certainly make this again! We're grateful, Sue...thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can only review the slow-cooking method of this recipe because I prepared my chicken as I usually do - squeezed a lemon over top, sprinkled it with salt, pepper and poultry seasoning then put it into the fridge overnight.  I rubbed the skin with olive oil and put half a lemon, half an onion and some garlic cloves in the cavity before roasting.  Cooking at 250 degrees for 5 hours made the chicken wonderfully moist and flavorful yet it still maintained it's shape (I don't really like when it falls off the bone).  I did baste the chicken during the last half of the cooking process. I'll do this again when I'm home for an entire afternoon.

The chicken did fall off the bone. In fact, when I sliced into the leg to see if it was done, the leg started to fall off the chicken! The meat was fairly juicy. I think the flavor could've been better. I only cooked one chicken, for about 4 hours instead of the full 5 hours, and halved the amount of spices. Refrigerated overnight. I put a quarter of a lemon into the chicken cavity before cooking. Didn't use the onion inside. Will probably make again, and might make some adjustments next time.
